text: Do you wanna rock!? Or go beyond the exhausting thrill of bouldering? Besides the maze of different walls to challenge yourself. This facility offer belay lessons to take your experience to a whole new and exciting level.I was lucky enough to get Remo as my instructor. She was patient and took the time to go over all the proper safety steps with me until i was confident enough to belay with a partner. She was the best teacher I've probably has since the good ol school days. You can tell she loves her job as well as the love for the sport. The facility inside is tight but nicely outfitted with a variety of walls for every skill level. And it's also great for kids and offers an upstairs where one can plan out a climb party. They have different types of memberships for the ones that just can't get enough. The restrooms are kept and the staff members are helpful and informative. And that's my take on this hanger of pain,Peace out

I signed up for the special during the holidays to get a month of climbing for a low fee. I figured I could go once or twice with family while I was in the area. I come to find out they have been charging me $72 for the past 5 months without my knowledge. I was never told that this was a repeat charge that I'd be locked into paying. I am livid with myself for not realizing they were doing this faster but also terribly mad at the franchise for misleading customers like that. Shame on you Hanger 18. Get some morals and stop cheating your customers.

I used to come to this gym a lot, and actually really liked it. However, the last two times I went, they had a class that closed up the only two solo belays in the entire gym. I waited one time for more than an hour, as I was told it would end soon. Spoiler, it didn't. The second time I just left because I already knew better. I used to come here almost daily, but now I go to other locations, because I know that if I go alone, I can either boulder or go home. ‍ When I complained the second time, I was give a genuine, "I'm really sorry for the inconvenience", which is nice, but honestly, I pay for my membership just like everyone else. They have more than enough space to use in the gym for the class, which is why I really don't understand, and shutting down the only two auto belays so all the rest of us have no option isn't acceptable for paying customers. Guess I'll just keep going to the other locations ‍

Cheap and decent.I got a membership for two months after taking a break for a year. I figured it's cheaper than going back to Touchstone. I think I paid $30 or so a month for this Hanger membership which really doesn't bite compared to the $100 per month. The grading here is definitely harder, which I like. It's a cool place for the price, but I'm not too fond of the crash pad and the huge crowd. I only climbed one time there and was floored with how a lot of members neglected safety. I saw a relatively huge whipper with people underneath. Little kids climb and jump off the boulders without watching. It's a good place, but I saw things I won't go back for.

This is an update NOT about the second or third time I've revisited this fine establishment.  It's an update about my first and last time climbing here.  A continuance of what I wrote as the first review.  I stand by every single letter and am not changing my mind about anything, regardless of all the other positive reviews.It's been five and a half years, going on six, and the case I have with Hanger 18 is finally over.  After 5 different lawyers, 120 phone calls (I'm rounding up on the phone calls), 4 appeals, I'm left with zero savings, one fractured spine, a pair of legs that will never ever know what's it like to be in the sleeves of a pair of pants and an impending doom of the defense coming after me, for the rest of my life, to pay for their attorney fees.  I'm leaving out a lot of other little details, but that's about the gist of it.  Nobody wants to hear or is interested in all the nitty gritty particulars, so I'm not going to bore anyone anymore on that, let along repeat myself for the 200th time (again, rounding up).This update is just to let anyone know, who is willing to take a second (or 30, it's long, but it's not that long) and read, the heeded fable of what happened here and I'm sure, will happen to someone else.  I'm not the first one to fall and be severely, permanently, damaged and I will not be the last.With all the gross negligence of this gym and their ridiculous brush with borderlining requirements, it's amazing that they haven't closed down.  I guess this is where it pays to have excellent insurance and big money to pay resourceful lawyers that can get them out of any jam with any judge.  I still haven't lost my interest and love for rock climbing, it's truly, truly, a great sport, but please, if you are going to participate in this great work out, find a place that does their research and know how to protect their members.  If I wasn't so financially crippled by this ...establishments, I'd be out there climbing rocks and jumping out of planes all day. Money can be earned but our bodies cannot.  (Not yet, at least.)  Once some things are damaged, they are always going to be damaged.  I'm not even 30 and I already know what it's like to live like an 80 year old.  Well, maybe not all the 80 year olds, some of them are still pretty painless.  Anywho, this isn't a ploy to get anyone to feel sorry for me or to tell me how great life is after 80, I know it can be great and I love my life the way it is.  This is a ploy to get people to know what a cut-corner-kind of place this gym is and the people who own it as well as the people who represent it.My case my be a SNAFU, but I'm a UFANS - Un-Fudgedly Awesome, Nameless Situation - A reverse acronym I just made up.  Shut up, I know it's not that good.  I just made it up!

Staff was very friendly and helpful. Climbs are good fun, they have a great mix of routes. They offer auto so you can do more than Boulder when you come alone. Only complaint is that there's no place to fill your water bottle besides the bathroom sinks! :( What kind of gym doesn't have a water fountain?! Climbers should be working together to try and take care of our planet not making people buy pointless single use plastic at the gym!
Cool place. Crappy customer service and people skills though. If you're new to climbing be ready to be treated like a moron instead of feeling welcomed and helped.

I'll admit facing my fear of heights here was terrifying, but Hangar 18 does a fantastic job of making rock climbing accessible and easy to any level climber!Our dear friends invited us as a part of a Groupon deal so I mustered up all the courage I had to try something new. Upon arrival we were asked to fill out waivers and orientation checklists on personal iPads. It was my first time, but the staff does offer hour classes for anyone to become accustomed to the equipment. They also offer rental shoes and harnessess $3 per person!The actual rock climbing walls were maintained well and labeled for difficulty. They also offer powder to enhance your performance as your hands do get sweaty climbing up. There is also extremely nice restrooms with a small locker room (bring your own lock) to store any clothes or belongings.I had such a fun time challenging myself here and watching others do the same. Highly recommend this place to anyone looking to learn to rock climb!

My kid and I recently started climbing, and we like the gym very much overall. My only complaint is regarding the blonde chick at the front desk. Like, by all means, please finish your conversation while I stand here awkwardly waiting to return the items that I paid to borrow. I'll wait for you. My kid thinks she's "snappy", too. So there's that. You work in a super dope ass place- have a better attitude.

Great activity to do with friends!I have been wanting to go here for so long and I finally got a couple friends to go with me. I purchased a day pass for $21 (or $22) for myself. Upon entering, I had to fill out 2 lengthy digital forms at their ipad station. Checking in took longer than expected because the front desk was so busy. I would come in 15 mins early to get forms filled out and to beat the rush of people.After checking in, my more experienced friends and I chose to try bouldering the easier v0 and v1 options. I really enjoyed the wide range of climbs that that they offered. I found one called the "squatty potty" where you started in a squat position with your hands on two poop shaped grips. It was a great laugh and fun to try.We stayed for about 2 hours. I wish I could have stayed longer but I was just too tired and my hands already ripped. Overall, this place is large enough to come with a group and the atmosphere is very friendly. I found multiple times that strangers helped us find the right footing and holdings while climbing. Great workout and great fun. Check them out if you haven't already!

Customer service is a definite 1 star here. They seem underpaid due to their angst on doing their job. The rental shoes definitely have fungus growth due to their overwhelming foot stench. The only sense of safety really comes from the orientation videos which were great but still confusing. The waivers we signed are extraordinarily ridiculous because the staff just gives you harnesses and push you along so they can get back to talking to their friends about gossip or whatever they did last weekend. But hey, i paid the cost plus the fees and i climbed so i guess this is another place i wouldn't recommend. Bring extra socks because the funus transfer from their equipment into your shoes is serious.

Climbed here, and occasionally at other Hangars, for about a year. I've climbed elsewhere previously, so this review is flavored by comparisons to my other experiences in the Bay Area/central Oregon.Firstly, this pricing is legit. I don't think I can get a $35/mo membership, or a $300/year membership on Groupon, anywhere else I've ever been. For that price you can go to any of the Hangars, which are all a lil' different. But I'll focus here on Upland.There is a solid amount of bouldering and lead set-ups at this location. Two new auto-belays. Limited options for top-rope, but enough for new folks to shimmy on up. The routes can be really cool/brain teasey, even if the grading seems, to me, sporadic and stiff (but I'd probably take that last bit with a grain of salt, since I'm a pretty casual climber who has plateau'd at V3s. Sometimes I can climb V4s here. Sometimes I can't get up their V2s. It was frustrating at first, but after a while, it bothered me less, and I'll just try whatever). Staff have generally always been nice to me, but are maybe kinda hands off, so if you need 'em, holler. It's not my favorite gym in the world, and not the most aesthetic or clean gym. No bells and whistles. No AC either, for that matter, but there's fans... And lots of chalk (; Just skimming other reviews here and thought to say, for first timers - if you're worried about falling badly/don't yet trust yourself to fall well, I'd consider trying top-roping first instead of bouldering.
Good place to climb. Belay lesson was very clear. New membership is affordable. Though it's smaller then the one in Riverside, but it's closer for me.

This was our second time here and it was not the same experience. Our kids felt the workers were a little rude and not very friendly. Friday is definately a place for the "regulars" and not for any newbies. One of the climbers yelled at my son.  And a worker yelled and humiliated a Spanish speaking parent who climbed for 5 seconds without paying and was scolded in front of everybody.  Probably will find another place to take the kiddos.

Came here June 24 with my 3 other people. Terrible experience with using Groupons, their waiver system, and the workers there.We had 2 groupons for "2 intro to rock climbing classes". We came in 1.25 hours before closing but they said that they don't give out lessons after a certain time. NO WHERE DOES IS THAT MENTIONED ON THE GROUPON. I already drove 45 mins to get here so I don't want to come back another day, plus I was leaving for college the next day and won't be able to use the Groupons before they expire. The worker gave us the option of bouldering so we did that. I've done the rock climbing class at Riverside but my brother, cousin, and friend haven't. My brother and cousin have been to this Upland location before for bouldering so their waiver was already in the system. However it took the front desk 10 mins to pull up my waiver from Riverside, they had to call the Riverside location to finally confirm it. This was my friends first time at a Hangar 18 location so he had to fill out a new waiver. After submitting it, he had to wait for a confirmation email but it never came in so they had him fill out the waiver again. Waited more, still no confirmation email, so he had to fill out the waiver another time! Finally got this waiver confirmed AFTER THREE ATTEMPTS and 35 MINUTES OF WAITING.After confirming the waiver we only had around 40 mins left to do stuff. None of the workers even bothered to explain how bouldering works or safety precautions. My friend who has never done bouldering before was completely lost and I had to explain to him what to do.The Groupon states all gear is provided, but I guess that is only rock climbing gear. When I went to the front desk for chalk, they said it isn't included. You would think since we weren't rock climbing(so already not using any of their material) and with our time they wasted waiting for the waiver system, they could at least lend us some chalk, but nope. No compensation at all.I'm writing this review really late because I tried contacting them about my poor experience, to see if they could do anything about it. But one month later and I still have not received a response. Overall I was disappointed with this Hangar 18 location. Not worth the drive, my time, or the price I paid for the Groupon.

Went for a birthday party of my daughter's friend. At first she was skeptical about this place because she never been to one. The staffs are super friendly and fun. They taught the beginners tricks and tips how to climb the walls. Of course my daughter got too excited and kept on challenging herself to try the harder and harder obstacles. There were different levels and they color coded them. We loved this place. She even think of doing her birthday there too. That was an awesome party for like 7years and up, up, up. Means adults will enjoy this place too.

Thrill seekers, rock climbing enthusiasts, and lovers of scraped hands and peeled skin rejoice! This is the perfect place to get all that, and a full-body workout without actually going to the gym. The place is spacious enough to accommodate large groups of people with room left over, and the climbs themselves are suited for people of all levels; though, beginners will have a tough time the first few tries. It won't take long for you to realize that as easy as it looks from the ground, you will need to train your body to move in ways it's not used to and use muscles that you didn't even knew you had to keep your hold/ balance on these walls. The cool part is that they have both free climbs, where you're not strapped into anything, as well as harness climbs that will take you all the way to the ceiling- in the safest way possible, of course. It's perfect for people who need a bit of a rush in their lives.The memberships start off pretty affordable, but get more and more expensive as the months go along. I guess they're confident enough in the addictive nature of rock climbing that they know you'll want to pay upwards of $30 a month just to keep a membership there. If you live nearby, however, and you happen to hate the gym or working out normally, you're in luck. When you're a member, you can go every day, and stay as long as your heart desires/ your hands and body hold out.For newbies, I highly recommend finding someone who has a membership and using one of their free monthly guest passes to scope the place out before you sign up yourself. I also recommend buying a cheap bag of chalk powder at your nearest sporting goods store as your hands will be feeling the burn after the first few climbs. If you decide this is your new home away from home, you may also want to invest in some rock climbing shoes of your own, as renting them here will cost you $3 a pop, and may or may not make your feet smell really badly. Hey, you never know who has used these things.Good luck up there. Safety first!

So I read a ton of reviews before we went yesterday. A lot said it's hot and the staff are unfriendly yada yada. I personally was there for a tween birthday party. I was way too early, but the staff ,Chris & ?? , I can't remember the names, they all had big friendly smiles and were so kind and helpful. Yes, it's warm in there, but it's not a day spa or luxury movie theater, so get over it. Even the 2 girls that were in charge of our group were super sweet and informative with my many questions. I can't say what the experience would be had I just walked in the place on my own as a first timer. But my experience with everyone I came in contact with was customer service A+. My daughter had tons of fun and went up 11 times in the hour + we were there. She wants to go back.

I'll give this place two stars because it was a fun experience. But the employees are very condescending to first timers. They seemed annoyed at any questions. What really threw me off about this place is when I went to throw my water bottle away. As soon as it went in the bin I hear an angry "NOOOOOO" coming from the Caucasian blonde girl that works there. She pulled it out of the garbage shoved it at me and said "dude fuckin recycle" in those exact words. I wasn't aware there was a recycle bin back at the entrance. The asian guy was somewhat nice though. But ppl like that girl are just giving your place a bad name. I've never been talked to like that at any establishment and I won't be back.

I am a rock climbing gym rat. Yea, you heard me. I have done some cool climbs outdoors, but most of the last 9 years have been spent inside a comfortable gym with an average approach of 50 feet from car to wall. So just trust me when I say that I have been to a ton of different climbing gyms. Hangar 18 in Upland is... "special". Let's start with the facility. It's an old airplane hangar. Cute. That doesn't sound so bad right? I'm pretty sure if you left a small child alone in there, they would develop lead poisoning. Don't worry though. The lack of air conditioning or basic insulation will ensure they die of heat stroke first. Also, don't go with an open wound. The polished holds will most likely give you a staph infection after you're done flailing on that V2+. Did I say "sandbagged"? Sorry I meant "cemented". It took me 3 months to discover that they actually vacuum the floor. I just assumed that the clumps of hair on the ground paid rent, along with the dirt and loose chalk. Do you like to climb during the hours of 3pm to 9pm? You're in luck! There will only be 200 people there when you show up. Smelly elbow room and nowhere to put your stuff is cool right?In addition, this gym is on a long list of places that bans the use of the ATC. Have you ever belayed a lead climber with a Grigri before? Neither have I because I'm not an insane person who likes to make my life harder than it already is.Ughhhhhh. Ok, ok I'm done. And after all that... this place isn't so bad. You know why? $35 bucks a month. That's why. You get what you pay for. There are definitely some good qualities too. The setting is decent, the walls are moderately high, and the staff is pretty cool. Yea this place isn't the ritz, but at least they aren't ripping you off. And in the world of endless, picky Yelp reviews, isn't that what matters most?

I was hesitant to come here. My manager said it was a cool place but I read a lot of reviews stating poor customer service and the staff being rude. I'm also completely new to bouldering and know very little about it (sorry if I fudge up the terminology or am wrong about something)I don't know if other reviewers have their panties in a bunch or if I just lucked out on who helped me, but I had a pleasant experience, almost exactly how I would want to be treated. (Unless you ask questions or look like you're having issues, they leave you alone to fill out the forms [2 forms for adults], give succinct explanations of the rules and how it works there, and give you free rein after you pay)The cost for a day pass is $18 while monthly membership is $36, so membership is definitely something to consider. I'm still on the fence since this is close to work not home, which means I have to bring another set of clothes each time and would only come here after work. (They have multiple locations but none near my house, closest would be a 30min drive)Shoe rentals are $3. They were really helpful and nice about shoes. They explained that they will be very snug fits for usage purposes but if they were too uncomfortable, I could switch them at anytime. I did have to switch sizes after 2 climbs because they were too tight. I didn't experience anything rude, condescending, removed, or anything negative in general from my interactions, questions, and request.TL;DR customer service is good.The facility itself looks alright, a bit smaller than what I thought it would be. There are very bouncy floors for the bouldering areas which made me feel safe in case I fell. Place doesn't look dirty, it doesn't look pristine clean, but that's what I'm expecting when you have tons of sweaty people with their hands covered in chalk. A wide range in difficulty available and it's at most a small wait to climb the wall you want.So why not 5 stars?1 star is docked for a few nit picky details and what I felt was lacking.What was lacking: More beginner routes, maybe separate them as well so it's easier for new people to navigate. There's a limitation on space so not everyone can be catered to, but I think there should be one easy incline wall for newbies to start on. Lockers would be cool. There are cubbies under the benches for you to put your stuff. I don't think people will go through/swipe your stuff; but you just feel more secure with your stuff locked away. Nit picky: A/C would be nice. Didn't need it the evening I went since it was cool enough. I imagine it would be uncomfortable in a hot summer afternoon Fans they're using look nasty. I get they're hard to reach and maintain, but the dust build up on them is pretty significant. I don't particularly care other than for aesthetics since I have no health issues, but I imagine some people would find it concerning.Bottom line: Good place, especially if you opt for membership. This is a gritty place as the sport itself is tough, so don't go in expecting a luxurious comfy upscale setting and service. The employees are just regular people being themselves. I wouldn't recommend going on your own if you're not in the best of shape since you'll be on your own and even the beginner bouldering walls can be challenging. The rope climb/belay has that perk of whoever is helping you, could probably assist you in addition to keeping you safe. I haven't tried this, but my first time rock climbing, my partner would step back to help pull me up on parts I struggled on.

Screw this place my son and I waited hours between waiting, filling out their legal documents and watching their video. They over sold their memberships for the Thanksgiving weekend $10 sale. We paid $13 for the day pass plus rental for $19 total. We had a terrible experience and looking at first time experience and they would not refund our money. My son could not even hook up to climb or get a training session in just on big waste of time. I am very sad and my son was upset and was really looking forward to learning how to climb. Too bad I can't give 0 stars, hours wasted and $19 non refunded.

I had an introductory lesson today (via groupon - GREAT deal!).  It was such an AMAZING experience that I simply HAD TO write a review!  We were a group of four and Ethan was our instructor .  Ethan  was AWESOME!  I know nothing about rock climbing  - a blank slate in the truest sense!  Ethan was SO Patient!  He made you feel like there was all the time in the world . This was after explaining the same thing to me FOUR times!!! There was never ANY sign of impatience or annoyance. Only encouragement and a Can DO attitude!  There was so much laughter!   I had a WONDERFUL experience!  The facility was clean and everyone was helpful and friendly - including the other climbers.  I will definitely be back!

This place is awesome! I came here with 2 other friends (who have never climbed before) and they were pretty nervous. John was extremely helpful and very patient with us! We bought the intro package for $33 and since it was BOGO that day, we each paid $22! We learned how to belay and boulder. After rock climbing for about 3 hours, we decided to get the membership and paid the difference from the original package we got. Highly recommend for newbies and anyone interested in rock climbing:)

First time visitor, called the Rancho spot and they recommended me to the upland spot instead since my kid was young. Stopped by this morning right as they opened, staff was very cool and helpful. Had to sign a lot of waivers and misc documents a it was our first time but after completion we were ready. Went through the class on how to belle (if that is how it's spelled) and my daughter and I were ready. As she just turned three this week it was more of a trial to see if she was down and would like it or nor. Harnessed up and belle ready a she went all the way up the wall the first time. Came down and said "Papi, I try again please". Great time, will be going back, thanks H18

Fun place to check out. Definitely had doubts on how fun and tough bouldering could be but it's different when you're hanging about 7-8 feet from the air and you need to reach/propel yourself to the next grip. I was faced with a predicament... do I try and reach and risk falling and snapping something up or just jump off... I opted to jump off haha. FYI you really won't snap anything up... just a fear I had until I finally decided to go for it and fell. It's a great time and lots of cool and helpful people. Very busy at nights so recommend going during mornings or afternoons, if able.

Great place ! We had my daughter's birthday party here this past weekend. We all had such a great time. The staff made everything really easy and helped us in all kids of ways. Cleaning and setting up the tables , cleaning up after , making sure all the kids were being challenged and included in the climbing. Thank you for making our daughters celebration a success!
Awesome place. Good people. Need to get my own pair of climbing shoes, tired of paying rental fee...

Very cool place! My bf and I were new so we did a one on one instruction for $30 each and afterwards we could do some bouldering or whatever for the rest of the day. But after 2 hours your hands, forearm etc will be so exhausted! They let us use the chalk for free which was super nice because I know they charge for it.

This place is terrible! I have been to many rock climbing places but the some of the employees are so rude! And the customers are also rude! And hog everything! Also this place is very hard to find if your not local.I don't recommend this place to anyone. Sender one in Santa Ana is unbelievable and I recommend it to everyone! They are so friendly and not cocky! Everyone helps everyone. And Sender one is 10 times bigger then hanger 18.

Wanted to rock climb so a friend brought me along with him to Hangar to give it a try. When I first walked in I was so confused as to what I needed to do. I had never rock climbed free hand before, I had always rock climbed using a rope. They have two laptops at the front desk and in the beginning I just stood there playing around with it to see what I needed to do. Then after a good 10 minutes or so, a staff member asked me if I needed help. I signed the waivers and then asked him how much it would be for rentals and such. My friend had the membership, and apparently with that you can bring a friend in once a month for free, so I wasn't charged for the day. I believed it was 20$ for the shoes though. According to other reviews, they don't provide the chalk and you have to pay for it, but I always see people bringing in their own, as my friend did as well. Walking around I imagined it to be a lot bigger, but i guess it's pretty spacious for an indoor rock wall. I barely made it through the level 0's and 1's and my hands were getting sore. I made the wrong choice in wearing both a black tshirt and a black leggings as the chalk just covered everything. Overall, it was a great experience, but it's way too far of a drive for me to come back just to rock climb.

So impressed with this place! Brought my unit of American Heritage Girls for a Climb On badge. Ethan taught the class and the girls had a blast. He was clear, friendly and very instructive without being at all boring. The other Ethan, I think he's the manager, was super accommodating. Our troop looks forward to having more events here. Nice energetic atmosphere!

First time here...first ever climbing experience. The staff here were friendly and helpful. My girlfriend and I took the intro course for top roping to learn how to properly use the gear and...how not to fall and die. There were 4 of us total during the intro course and the instructor gave us enough one-on-one attention to make sure we understood everything. I was pretty nervous about our first climb on our own without the instructor...but by the second climb, I felt more confident. It was fun, thrilling and tiring. If I remember correctly, I think there were 9 "routes" that were spaced pretty close together. I was glad that we came early enough (around noon) to beat the rush of people. The atmosphere there was pretty diverse. Even though we were beginners, we didn't feel out of place. There were other first timers and others who were much more experienced. The age ranged from very young kids to older adults.
Good place to climb and nice people, but mislead us about the cost/pricing for when we returned.

This is my 2nd climbing gym I've gone to. Fortunately, it is way better than my 1st one. How so? 1. The employees. They are knowledgeable (which you expect they'd be experts when it comes to climbing activities) and helpful with tips if you only ask. 2. The gym itself. They have free memberships for REI employees and possible discounted prices for other individuals ie. students. They also have classes you can and may want to attend such as belaying classes. 3. Customers/climbers. Environment is friendly due to the customers as well. If you're looking for help when it comes to any wall, if you can't find an employee, trust that another climber will give you some pointers. Overall, it's fun working out and having a positive vibes from other climbers/gym goers. They have multiple locations so don't hesitate to look around for the location near you.

I've been going to this location for about a month now.I definitely like their rental shoes here better than other locations because its more comfy.They have a lot of challenging ones for bouldering here but they also have top roping which i haven't tried yet.their staff are friendly.they have a lot of fans at this location but i prefer air conditioning.only one complain though... that one room with no window or any air circulation is the worst because kinda stink!

Awesome indoor rock climbing gym!I've been coming here for about three years now and even though they are smaller than some other climbing gyms, the customer service and belaying lessons are great! They have a wall designated for rock climbing and another adjacent wall for bouldering with cushioned mats all around. The skill level of the climbs are clearly labeled and they change it up pretty often.This past weekend I came with my bf to use a Groupon for a full day of climbing which included the belaying lesson and rental equipment. Our belaying lesson was taught by Mason and he was patient and very thorough in explaining all the details of how to tie the figure 8 knot and going through all the safety procedures, even though he had already taught several lessons for the day and was getting ready to leave. There are also several other locations of Hangar 18 in Riverside, Long Beach, South Bay, and Mission Viejo. I've only been to the Riverside location which is a lot bigger than the Upland location. Tip* Look out for Groupons and special deals on their website! It saved me a lot of $$$.

My friend Brittany invited me to try this place out. Neither of us had ever rock climbed before but we are always up for a fun challenge. Our Instructor Mason was so sweet & super knowledgeable, we had a blast! We will definitely be back!! Thanks Mason!!
The atmosphere and chill attitude of the employees is awesome.  Also tons of bouldering.

I'm going to start this off by saying that I'm an absolute beginner and that my best at this gym was accomplishing some V0s. Adding to that, I've also had the pleasure of visiting Rock City in Anaheim before coming here, and I can say that this Hangar 18 is the bigger of the two. There's the option of top-roping, bouldering, and lead climbing with plenty of routes and space for all 3. The employees here are friendly and although they had some issues checking me in the first two times, they were very apologetic about the situation. You'll see them walking around from time to time to give pointers (when asked) and to make sure people are being safe (i.e. not standing too close beneath friends while one is bouldering).While I make it a point to try and avoid Tuesdays because it seems to be more crowded, you'll notice people of all levels climbing on different days at night. If you want to save time, make sure you complete the waiver before arriving (climbhangar18.com/waiver…)!P.S. Check groupon for deals! I scored 2 one month membership for $53 (the price of 1 one month membership) that includes all rentals whereas a day pass is $16 per day.

Upland, Upland, Upland.This is the first rock climbing gym I've ever been to and let's just say they sold me on rock climbing. My brother had been climbing for a few months before I started so I came in with his monthly guest pass (free for the day with rental shoes included). The staff was energetic, positive, helpful and really made me feel welcome. They have a promotion going on where the first month is just $5 and after my first day there, there was no hesitation signing up.The facility has belaying on one side and bouldering on the other. It can get crowded at times, but the climbing community is generally very respectful of each other's space. The routes are changed periodically, giving you plenty of time to work through certain problems if you get stumped. But it's often enough that you don't get bored doing the same problems over and over. It can get a bit hot inside with so many people climbing, but to be honest, it's never been a big issue for me. The padding on the bouldering side also seems fairly new so I definitely appreciate that. I've been to the Long Beach Hangar 18 and their mats are stiff and unpleasant (didn't realize how much I appreciated Upland until after I climbed in LB).So for those of you who have always wanted to give rock climbing a shot, I highly recommend  Hangar 18 in Upland. Take advantage of that promotion while it's still here!

Been an off an on member of hangar 18 for a while now. I live far from any gym so I cant go very frequently. I would keep my membership when I could and cancel it when I couldn't go for a few months. I was told by an employee the last time I signed up I was able to cancel anytime over the phone, this was very convenient for me and allowed me to be a member much longer. When I finally needed to cancel it over the phone, Ethan (the manager) at Upland told me that is not allowed and has never been. He was extremely rude about it and even told me, "no that is not what you were told." Insinuating that I am a liar, I know what I was told. Just due to how rude Ethan was Hangar 18 has lost my business forever. I hope the rest of your locations have better management and customer service in place.

Had to cancel my membership because I had wrist surgery. Received a call from an employee at the upland location that my card Info had changed so I needed to pay for the previous month and the current month (not a problem) I explained that I wanted to cancel and he said okay, I'll charge you for one month and then you'll have a free month if and when you want to return (so they would waive one months fee since I'm not able to climb)Looked at my bank account to find a charge for 81 dollars, which doesn't make sense even if I were to pay for the full 2 months since the membership is something like 32 a month. I called back requesting a return call so I can figure out why I was charged for 81 dollars....this was a few days ago and still no return call. Riverside location is way more customer friendly.

Meh.The two staff were overwhelmed with amount of people coming in. Doing too many things at once, ie: answering phones, signing in new people, teaching intro classes. I was irked by the fact that the desk boy was a snob when I mentioned the Two for Tuesday day clearly advertised on their website after he tried to charge me for both of our day passes. His almost verbatim comment, "Oh we don't mention that and for good reason, but you know if you ask for it, we will give it to you." Um what exactly it that suppose to mean? You don't offer the same offers on your page unless someone asks for it? That would be like me going to a happy hour and ordering drinks but being charge regular price because I didn't mention it was their happy hour. But I digress.As others have mentioned, their holds are filthy and frankly the gym is just too crowded for it's own good. Having climbed at Threshold in Riverside (before it joined the Hangar 18 family) I am use to an open space, ample places to sit and actually missed the experience of being able to top out. As someone who has brought several friends with them to other gyms, it would have been nice to have seen one or two V-B climbs somewhere for true newbies. There's nothing super wrong with this gym it's simply not my cup of tea.I basically walked into Hangar 18 ready to sign up for monthly memberships for two people but decided to pass.

They charge you $21 for one day my wallet feels violated. Chalk isn't provided which is an abuse of the captive consumer as blisters form without it. Chalk is $4 and it is not the $4 that gets to me. It's the fact that they think $21 per day isn't enough to cover chalk. We are using THEIR equipment and it is their equipment that causes blisters. They don't have the courtesy to provide chalk powder which is dirt cheap. With that logic those who decide to save $4 deserve blisters?

This was my first time going to any Hangar 18, I usually go to Rock City in Anaheim (great place!), and it definitely didn't disappoint! The entire place is pretty spacious and has a wide variety of different climbing levels that can satisfy people at any skill level. Each climbing trail is clearly marked with the difficulty and also a unique name. The left side of the building is for climbing with the rope, and then the right side is for bouldering. They also have a little room in the back that's for bouldering as well. My group came at night and they were pretty understaffed at the time, but Isaac did a great job of trying to accommodate everybody who needed help. He was teaching people how to work the ropes, signing people in, and helping out the climbers; super nice and overall a great dude. I also watched him do a bouldering trail that was pretty high in difficulty while wearing jeans, just to demonstrate for another climber; he probably finished it within 10 seconds. How the fuck do you do that?!Overall I had an excellent experience at Hangar 18 Upland. Great place to get your climb on and the service there is awesome, everyone there is super friendly and willing to give you pointers. Definitely recommend going here with your friends.

Overall: Had a Groupon so for $15/person, it was a great experience for the price. But perhaps a bit underwhelming for the general $33.Location/Ambience:Located within a warehouse-like building, it is pretty hard to find/may seem a little dead in the surrounding areas especially during weekdays. However, any skepticism of the place is negated once you step inside - it is actually v pretty with all the colored rocks. The place in itself is not meant to handle huge amounts of crowds, so avoid morning hours especially during breaks. Around 1pm, it started dying down and theres no wait time to climb any of the levels.Experience:With our package, they offered lessons which is definitely needed. Lessons happen at the hourly (11am, 12pm, etc) so be cautious of the time you arrive. 1. Come in, sign your life away with liability forms and orientation checklist. Receive harness + shoes. 2. Wait til hourly lesson. They teach you the four checks and basics of knotting and safety of coming down. Our instructor Isaac was super helpful and patient. Warning: This is a partnered activity and you will need a second person to pull the rope as you climb.3. After a bit practice with the instructor, you are free to climb anything you want for as long as you want. There's many different levels but unless you are a natural with much upper body strength, the kid ones are where its at. An hour or two of switching off between the climber & rope handling, we were pretty much done with it. Its a decent size, but as a beginner there's only so many you can climb.

Brought a group of 12 children and teenagers to Hangar 18 in Upland today and we had a great time! Everyone in our group was very happy with their lesson from Isaac and checkin with Brad. Those two guys are great! Friendly and patient with our entire group of newbies. They made the kids feel comfortable and welcome to be there. It was great to see even the most timid and shy kids in our group try something new and out of their "comfort zone"! Great job Hangar 18 Upland, Brad and Isaac! You were wonderful to our kids ranging in age from 7 to 20 years old! Many of the group intend to return!

Quick background: I'm fairly new to climbing. A pretty solid 5.10a top rope climber and about a v1-v2 on bouldering. The boyfriend and I are frequent climbers at the Long Beach location (like at least 3x a week) but we were up in Rancho Cucamonga to do our taxes and our gear was in the gear, so hey, why not? The location is pretty well-hidden, tucked down a small street in a large warehouse. I really liked the atmosphere there on a Tuesday afternoon. No stinky smells, beautiful natural light coming in through the big windows. Just a nice peaceful vibe for a bouldering session.The bouldering is varied and extensive here, with a couple topout sections where you can climb onto the second floor and take the stairs down. I hope they're working on a gym section or something cool here because it's great space that's not utilized right now. The V1s don't seem to have as much of a learning curve as the Long Beach location, which I liked a lot.Top-rope seemed to be fairly varied, too, and they have a crack! I'm a little new at crack climbing but it seems so challenging and hard that I really wish Long Beach's top-rope section had a crack so I could practice. Overall, if I had a free day, I'd totally drive all the way out to check it out again. Great spot!

"At first I was afraid, I was petrified"Sorry no Groupon sob story here. I showed up after my friend Kristi had told me about this place and had urged me to go. I don't normally do things like this but fortune favors the bold and it was the Year of Will. When I got here, it was a little intimidating. I was there on a day pass and there were quite a few veterans already there. There's huge walls with an alphabet soup of colors and shapes on them. Mason was there to get me all signed up, get me all set with the shoes, and the basics. Mason also taught us how to properly belay using the GriGri. I actually had a lot of fun that day and before leaving I decided to go all in and sign up for a membership. I probably would not have had done so if Mason was not as helpful or as accommodating as he was. The staff here is amazing. They aren't passive and you can tell that they are actively passionate and excited about getting people to climb and teaching people how to be become better climbers. I get it. You can climb a rock anywhere. For free (outside). But its the staff here and keep me coming back for more. Alyse, who works with Mason, is one of the sweetest girls you'll ever meet. She's got the brains, the beauty, and the brawns and she is truly passionate about helping you conquer that tough bouldering problem or about talking you through the crux on that tough top-rope route you've been stuck on. The people here are truly rock people; they aren't some high school kids looking to make some cheese on a part time job. They foster the development of the rock climbing community and they'll constantly push you and encourage you to be a better climber. Honestly, I owe Hangar 18--and by extension, Mason, Alyse, and the crew-- a huge thank you. They've turned a one-off field trip into a full on obsession.

Fun gym.The climbing here is good, a little crowded due to a shared layout but still a fun place to climb.Unfortunately the staff are TERRIBLE! Unhelpful, snob-ish and condescending. I'd like this gym a lot more if they hired some better help.

First time here with my son.  He has been in the past and loved it.  I learned how to belay the ropes for him to climb.  Ashley taught me the basics and away we went.  Would recommend for the teachers to watch more than once to make sure we don't drop anyone.  Other climber were cool and answered other questions I had.  Fun time to spend a few hours.  Next time will pay for myself to climb as well.  It was cool that they do not charge the parents to learn the belay class if the climber is your own kid.  Had a fun time,  good work out away from the ball field

Nice gym, HORRIBLE customer service. Emailed the manager, he offered me a pass to come try the gym again, then NVER RESPONDED. That customer service tactic only works if you actually come through with what you offer. Lame and unorganized.

Came here for sons bday and was very impressed with the place. Party area is upstairs and kids have their own wall to climb well more like 6 walls. Staff help with kids climb the walls but they can also climb the big walls if they want. All were included for the 2 hours we had th le area. Great place to have fun and kids really liked it.

I have had nothing but awesome climbs at this place. Top rope and bouldering are challenging and interesting. No funky gym smell and excellent lighting. Staff are helpful, very informative and eager to impart any knowledge they have. They always welcome us with a smile, eye contact, and remember our names. I'm not sure why some reviews say the staff are snobbish. They are super chill, boys of summer, "come on in the climbing is fine" type. Their relaxed air may be what comes off as snobbish but then just ask them and they're happy to help. 1 star off only because I really like top rope but I'm running out of choices for my level. Please add more top rope.  Pretty please!They just had new lead rope climbs installed today. Come try them out! I can't wait to be strong enough to try lead rope soon.

This gym is just awful. The reason for this low rating is mostly due to the incredibly rude staff. They always seem as if you are bothering them. I just recently climbed there and need to use a GriGri, which to get you can give them your keys. Somehow I ended up with one device and two carabiners. When I returned them I put the items on the desk and went to the bathroom because the employee was busy, so when I returned and asked for my keys an employee who I believe was Isaac, pretty much accused me of stealing a device! He kept telling me I did not return the device when I did. He finally handed me my keys making sure to let me know I did not return the device but he'd give me my keys anyways. SERIOUSLY?! What a jerk, and this wasn't the only bad experience I've had here. Riverside location is WAY better.
Been a member for over 2 yrs. Staffs are super friendly. It's my favorite climbing gym among all hanger 18 gyms.

This was the third Hangar 18 i have been to. (I've been to 5 so far) and I love this place. Textured walls are great cause it's more like the outdoors and it does wonders for helping you smear. The staff is super friendly. Shout out to Ethan. Everyone there is there to climb so people are friendly and helpful (some are). It's strictly bouldering which im fine with. I do love bouldering and sport climbing equally but I do Boulder a lot more. It's a great place to climb at, not too far from riverside so I've already been a couple times. The gym is still fairly new so the crash pads surrounding the entire gym are still pretty stiff. But overall I always look forward to going!

So far, not impressed. The staff is a couple of barely out of hs guys who stare at your dumbfounded as to why you're there. They tell you one thing and do another. Their timing is THE WORST. Talk about bad service. They stand around talking to their friends more than anything. They expect everyone who walks in to be an expert looking to kill time. Seriously,  they offer a groupon for beginners lessons and treat you like crap for not knowing anything and make you wait around for eveeeer.Long story short: save yourself the disrespect, headache, and most of all time & don't come here. We won't be coming back here & don't have anything nice to say about this place or the people who "work" here.

The Upland Hangar 18 is okay...it's much more spacious than the other Hangar 18 locations I've been to. If it is nearby, it's an okay place to go if you want to climb but here are some things to keep in mind:1. Day passes are now $18 (up from $15). this likely has to do with the fact that Sender One just went up from $22 to $24, but honestly given the size and variety, if Upland is going to be $18, I'd recommend just going to Sender One (especially if you have to drive far to get to Upland).2. The staff are generally not that polite and not that helpful...we spent a fair bit of time at the beginning just trying to get everything done that needed to happen to be able to climb and mostly were ignored as the staff were chatting--about non-work topics--with each other. This also resulted one of the staff members being somewhat lax about safety checks...it was okay because everyone in our party was experienced, but wow. Especially when the excuse was that the person didn't have time...he might if he spent less time chilling with colleagues.3. The routes, as with most gyms in the area, are rated in a rather inflated way. That's not really an issue, but do keep in mind that both the top rope and boulder ratings were very inconsistent and seemed to depend more on who had set them, not some kind of consensus. Additionally, very poor use of the gym space...of the non-bouldering area, at least 2/3 of the wall space was lead climbing only...if there was a high demand for lead climbing that would make sense, but nobody was lead climbing while many people were wanting to top rope. There were a lot of great looking routes on the lead wall, too, that would be great top ropes.But hey, if the gym is close or you already have a hangar 18 membership, I guess it's alright. Next time I'm visiting a gym that I'm not a member of, it will be Sender One.

Date night with wife.  First time time for us.  Signed the waiver online prior to arrival.  Sal (instructor was awesome) he recommended to use Groupon for better deal.  Paid $30 for both of us instead of anticipated $42.  About a 45 min safety instruction class (worth it!!).   Then we were set free to do our thing.  Shoes very narrow and small.  Regardless it was amazing.  Great workout and paid an extra $5 to have 30 day membership.   Lots of fun.

Came here yesterday for their Tuesday BOGO deal. I've only ever gone climbing at LA Boulders and that place was awesome! Compared to LAB, this place was small and crowded (I assume most people also take advantage of the BOGO deal). There are no lockers to put your belongings, but plenty of cubby space. Though I appreciate that the worker told us that climbers are known to be very honest people...I also grew up in the real world. Glad to say our shoes weren't stolen (thanks honest climbers!), but I'd like the added security of a locker. I feel like Hangar 18 has the bare bones for bouldering. Perhaps if I wasn't a novice climber, this place would seem better. But I was very limited in my routes due to my comfort level remaining around the V0-V1s (not their fault of course). But I didn't get much climbing time in because there were so many other people who wanted to climb those routes too. I also didn't like that there's no topping out. There is a real sense of accomplishment when you top out, and all I could do was touch the top and then climb back down. Blehhhh.But whatevs. I had good company, so I still had a great time :D

The good: The walls are pretty high with great grips/mounts if you try to overcome your fear of heights and practice indoor rock climbing. They have rental shoes and provide ropes for certain areas. This place is fairly big with room to keep your belongings in little storage areas in the center of the place. They also provide climber ' tape and powder to help you get through the climb. It made my rock climbing experience fun.The bad: There is a lack of climate control at this gym. If it's cold or hot outside, it's gonna be the same temperature inside. Another bad note is that the service is bad here. The only thing they're good for is getting rental shoes for you. From a guest perspective it only seems like two people are operating the gym. One is usually at the the desk and the other seems to just pass time climbing around the gym not really working.  The person at the desk seems to be also the one to teach the lessons with the ropes.  Every time I bring someone new, they always put me in for the later time. They teach it every 30 mins. While I was waiting I just saw the desk person chatting away with a friend and the other worker was walking around. So I wasted time just looking at them talk. The lesson only takes 15 mins. More about the bad service at this gym...i signed up at the gym in Rancho Cucamunga with three people under my name. I tried to cancel my membership at the upland location, but I couldn't cancel the membership because the worker (ELISA OR ALISA) could access it on her computer. She didn't want to help me out and told me to go to the gym in Rancho. I had to take it into my own effort to call the person in Rancho and deal with them because of the lack of service. The Rancho worker straightened everything out. When I tried to have the Upland worker talk to the Rancho worker on my cell's speaker phone she gave me a disgusted look and just called them on their work phone. I hate the service there so much I'm taking the time to write this review hoping this will be read.

[ PROS ]-Varied degrees of climbing levels are welcome and they have different level holds-Climbing rocks are changed pretty frequently to mix things up-Friendly staff! (I've read some negative reviews but a lot of the time they might be understaffed or have a rush of people come in on a slow day)- Membership includes rental gear, day pass, belay lessons, yoga sessions, and even a awesome day pass (including gear and belay lesson) for a friend every month.- You can freeze your account for as long as you want in case you decide you want to take some time off or get busy. The only catch is you have to go to the location to do so, no calling it in.- Kids are totally welcome! My 8 year old cousin who is around the size of the average 4 year old had a blast climbing. They gave him the kid's helmet and a full harness for extra protection. Kids are only warned about how hard some of the climbs can be.[ CONS ]- For those of us who don't like the heat, there ain't no AC (but I'm sure hardcore climbers don't care) They do have a lot of fans though.- The place is a bit small but I don't complain about it much, there's usually enough room to climb unless it's a crowded day.- The price is a bit steep but I'm lucky enough to have gotten the cheap deal earlier on for $23 a month.- No chalk provided free (but I'm not sure many places do that anyway)***Parking? It's really not big of a deal to park on gravel, I'm not sure why people are complaining about it. There's not a huge lot but definitely enough parking.

Haven't been here for a few years. First time I came I had a Groupon and had fun. Friend has a membership here and brought me on a guest pass. (They get one free guest a month) first time bouldering. Loved it! Drank my pre workout and flew up tge first easy walls before I hit the wall lol.

Not gonna lie, rocking climbing indoors didn't really seem appealing to me cause it didn't seem like it could be that fun... I was wrong! After a month of membership, it really grew on me! LOCATION: I definitely am not in the upland area all that much, but surprisingly the location is pretty sweet. It's in a residential / warehouse area? Though a bit secluded/quiet, I didn't feel sketched out. Plenty of parking! There's an independent storage that sells random antique/second hand stuff literally next door as well to check out. Also conveniently within walking distance of downtown upland for more small random antique shops/ coffee/ food!STAFF / CROWD: Everyone was actually really nice, welcoming, and courteous. I've never climbed before and both the new and old members always offered help whether it was with putting a rope on a specific climbing route or with tips for better climbing. MEMBERSHIP: I believe it like costs $53 for a month of membership. It offers free fitness classes and you can go as many time as you like within the month as well as for a free belaying class (to teach you how to use the harnesses and ropes when with a partner). It costs  $5 to rent a harness and shoes each visit. They also offer membership discounts through renewal promos, Black Friday sales, and holiday sales! Personally, my friends and I snagged a groupon promo, which was like $53 for two people for one month- entailing 1 free belaying class, free fitness classes, and 1 free guest pass at any of their locations! Their promos are pretty affordable/awesome!ROCK CLIMBING: Apparently they change up the climbing paths on the wall every week which was pretty sweet! The facility is a huge warehouse so it's pretty spacious and bright from natural sunlight coming through the ceiling. I've only been a member throughout December, and it's been pretty chilly during each visit, but once you start climbing, it's not as bad! You need a partner to belay you and vice Versa if you want to climb with a harness and ropes. There's also a free climbing section where you just climbing without ropes/harnesses- if go by yourself. There's also an advanced section where you can rope yourself onto the wall as you climb (you learn to rope yourself to the wall through 3 classes for like $40- just ask the staff). All the different climbing routes are labeled differently depending on difficulty level. There's an upstairs section for kids. I'd say rock climbing is an upper body workout... So if you want to get your guns on point for the gunshow, you should probably consider rock climbing :) RECOMMEND TO A FRIEND?: Yes! I'd recommend everyone of all ages to try at least one month of membership for you to be hooked! Definitely more fun than I anticipated :D.

I wouldn't recommend this place. I payed and tipped before climbing, that was a mistake the staff ended up having some attitude. You pay $60 for staff + tips, then $16 per person climbing for two hours. They take their sweet time when you're paying. They give you a safety speech for about 30 minutes then 15 - 20 minutes getting knots out of a rope to hang up. That doesn't include the time they wonder around and talk. You're really only getting maybe a little over an hour of climbing then divide that by 9 climbers. I won't be back!

Awesome staff Super friendly ! Classes were amazing  and educational ! Package deal pretty good deal ! Instructors are there 24/7 if you need help ! This place is huge ! Fun for the whole family ! My 8 year old loved climbing today !! Super fun !

I've only gone rock climbing once so I have nothing to compare this to... but I had an awesome time and would definitely recommend this place to anyone who wants to try it.My friend and I shared a groupon that was $30 total for both of us, and included a belay lesson and equipment/shoe rental, then you can climb anywhere in the gym to your heart's content.  The staff is very nice and helpful, and the climbs are labeled with the level of difficulty.For those who don't want to use ropes and harnesses, there are plenty of walls for bouldering.  I know there's mats and all, but it's still kind of scary.Yes, recommended and would definitely go again.

Came here for the first time yesterday and had a great time! Eric and Mason were both incredibly helpful and you can definitely tell that they value their work and their priority is safety. They made sure everyone understood how to safely and properly rock climb. We had a fantastic time and I would definitely come back!

New to rock climbing and had a pretty good first experience at Hangar 18. We went in on a Sunday late morning and was able to squeeze in their belaying certification lesson right before they got way too crowded for my liking. As a first-timer, I wanted to stay in the top rope area but was pretty much kicked out when a group of 20-30 people showed up (for an event I think?). Employees were friendly and we were lucky enough to have gone when they were offering 50% off a 1-month membership! Definitely plan on coming back on a weekday instead.

I bought the groupon for 2 and we called to see if we needed to make an appointment for lessons, and they told us we cannot use the groupon on the day you purchased it.I checked back on groupon and the fine print didn't say anything about not using it on day of purchase. So I called the Rancho location and they said sure we can use it but they do not have a beginner course.So I called back to Upland location and told them Rancho allows it but you do not??? They said the Rancho location should't being telling people that, and they are going to call them to ensure they tell no one else that.When I asked how come you don't just list it in the fine print,  that you cannot use it on the day of purchase, and they said they were aware that it was not listed on groupon fine print but are working on adding it.This is not my fault, but now I have to waste my time to deal with a groupon refund.Bad customer service!

This location is pretty cool. You can do a bunch of things here. 1) You can top rope. If you don't know how, the staff can teach you how to tie in and belay correctly. 2) You can Boulder. They have problems for beginners and advanced climbers, so you won't get bored. 3) There's lead climbing. With membership, you can take the lead climbing classes if you don't know how, 4 sessions total. 4) Yoga on Tuesday night, on the second level. 5) Throw a party there. Fun place to hold birthday parties for the little kids.

My husband bought us the groupon for this place. We'd never done this before and the staff was very cool and understanding. We did the belay with the harness and ropes first. Isaac instructed us and he was very thorough, patient, and cool! We both climbed the wall twice and took our turn being the belayer. It was fun! Afterwards, we tried the bouldering and that was fun but difficult! It seems most people go there for the bouldering as only we and another couple we on the belaying rock climb. I like the fact they have a lot of diversity for their climbs and Isaac told us they are always changing them out to keep it fresh and new. We could have paid a couple extra bucks more to get a month long membership, but opted not to at this time. The memberships are good at all of their locations, which is awesome. I would try it again!

I've been to many rock gyms and this one is probably the dirtiest I've seen. Aside from the poorly marked rocks in the bouldering area (from all the dirt accumulation), there was a nose-killing stench here that will take you back to your middle school PE locker days. In other words, they don't use tape to label a certain climb so when dirt overcomes the color of a rock, you can hardly see. To make matters worse, I still smelled like the onset of puberty after leaving the building. The bouldering was alright--not the best formats I've ever seen. If they worked on cleaning up this place, they definitely would deserve 4 stars. Go to the other locations for your hygiene's sake.On the bright side though, the staff was nice and I felt safe here on the bacteria ridden  floor/equipment.

Challenging routes that get rotated every few months.  Plenty of bouldering walls.HOWEVER, the layout of the place makes it super crowded in the middle since the seats are shared between boulderers and top ropers.  It also feels like a sauna during the summer season even with fans on.

I rounded up... It's a solid 3.5. I've been climbing at this Upland Hangar 18 for a few months now, and it's pretty great; I've also been to other climbing gyms around, and this one is the best. It has Top-roping, lead climbing, and bouldering. The crash pads consume 100% of the bouldering area, and a denser pad is over the top-rope/lead climbing area. It's a little but on the dirtier side, but once you realize that most of the dirt is actually chalk, it's not as bad. The bathrooms are pretty bad, but I don't spend much time in there anyway. Most of the staff is not out there to be your best friends... Or friends at all for that matter. When I was first getting my membership, I waited at the counter for a solid 10mins before being asked if I needed help. But after a few interactions, you get over it. I got a sweet deal because I am a college student, but it is a little pricey for the monthly fee... But it is worth it. The parking is occasionally atrocious. But if you go midday, it's not that bad. Overall, I recommend it. It's a good first date kind of place, if you're into that, and it's good time.

I'm writing this review because I miss Hangar 18 so much T__TI recently moved to NYC, and going rock climbing is either too inconvenient, or too expensive, or both. Majority of the places in NYC have a $70+ monthly membership, some with activation fees, some with contracts. I go to NYU so I do have access to the NYU climbing gyms, but Hangar 18 makes the NYU gyms look tiny.If you do the student discount, it's $28 a month. I believe you can get a similar deal on Groupon. That's actually a really good price, considering you get gear, shoe rental, plus belay lessons. If you go twice a month, it's basically worth it. The place is huge. There are plenty of bouldering and top rope problems. They change the routes very frequently, which is good so people don't get bored, but if you come after skipping out on a few days, you might find the route you are working on to have disappeared. I think the place has a good mix of problems as well. I'm a beginner, and when I left for NY, I was climbing V1-V1+ and attempting V2's, so to me, there were infinite number of problems left to do. Like I mentioned earlier, they change the route very frequently so there's no way you will run out of problems to do unless you are REALLY good. The climbing environment is pretty friendly too. Besides a few guys here and there who grunt loudly if they can't finish a climb, everyone else is nice. Some of them will even go out of their way to give you tips. The staff is usually friendly, but some of them do appear kind of stuck up, but hey... they are literally climbing pros who are way better than most, if not all of the climbers there. If you end up getting a membership there and want to avoid crowds, weekday mornings are your best bet. Otherwise, the place gets quite crowded, even on weekday nights. In short, I really miss going to Hangar 18.

the people at the front desk are friendly but...sometimes they seem like they just don't want to help...BUT, they do give good advice and even gave me advice on how to climb efficiently even for a beginner...the members are also pretty friendly and honestly, we are all there for a purpose and that is to become better.  I think H18 is a good place to learn...oh and the price is pretty much reasonable because arcadia rock climing (ARC).....53$ for monthly membership
My son and I, along with another family came here for the first time. We paid for intro lessons and the staff were very accommodating, knowledgeable, and friendly. My son had fun and a great workout.

This an amazing fun filled place. The price was very reasonable. The staff very professional. The helped guided us all the way. We had kids with us. They explained the techniques and safety rules in a very simple langue. I felt very comfortable. I would 100% recommend this place specially if you have kids and going for the first time. You will have a blast.
Super fun for all ages and abilities. Professional, helpful, and great exercise. Thanks for the lessons and skills.  Everyone loved the experience

This Gym Tightbouldering... tighttop ropin ... tight lead climbing .... tightnew routes every couple of weeks... tight The employees.. they tight Brad, he tightMason, he tightMaddy, she tight issac, he tight Aleece, she alright but she tight

Isaac and Mike were very knowledgable and helpful w/ both hangar18 policies/perks and climbing in general. I had previously only visited the Rancho Cucamonga site (once), which only had bouldering. My friend decided to join me yesterday at the Upland location where I was pleasantly surprised to see many many more routes for both climbing and bouldering. We both learned toproping (climbing) procedures and safety rules from Mike who was very patient (we had a few different groups of ppl taking the class at the same time). Though my friend and I both had a couple times where Isaac had to be more stern w/ us for our safety, we didn't end up on his 'bad' side, and he was very congenial in our talk at the end of our time there. Not only are the staff and facilities great, the people who go there are generally nice too. One of the women who participated in the belay lesson w/ her husband and son seemed to already have had climbing experience, and she kindly gave tips while we learned. Others in the bouldering section were generous w/ their tips, chalk, and space (e.g. made sure n00bs like my friend and I got a chance at the parts of the wall that were marked V0 [the easiest]). It was such an enjoyable experience for the both of us!N.B. it was a bit tricky to find since it seemed to be in an abandoned alley next to a strange warehouse that had a 'For Lease' sign, but I just trusted google maps, and it faithfully brought me to the right place. There aren't super clear marked spots for parking, but it seems like everything in that open area next to the Hangar18 building is free for parking.

This is a decent place. Emphasis on decent.They don't mark their routes with tape and as a result you get less creative and more limited routes. Additionally, the holds are DIRTY making it close to impossible to see what holds you are actually supposed to be using at times.  Found myself and a fellow climber trying to decipher what holds were blue and what holds were green at one point. Made for a fun Sherlock Holmes type of situation -- but I just wanna climb.Everyone is nice so there is a plus.  Tape could make this place so much better. Basically, I'll come here when I have to not when I want to.  Want to give two stars but feel bad about that so three stars it is.

If you are not a climber, this place will do just fine.  There's a nice area upstairs for birthday parties and what not.  You can climb up a few simple routes and call it a day.  But if you are a climber, it's not the best gym.They don't use tape - all the routes are set by the using same colored holds.  It's very difficult to figure out what is on route, especially with the boulder problems.  The holds are dirty and a lot of the holds are similar in color.  They put purple, gray, and black holds all in the same area and it was very difficult to distinguish.  When I touched the footholds to try to figure out what color they were, my fingers turned black.  Tape is just better.I was told one of the owners of the gym owns Climb-It Holds.  So all the holds are that brand.  Which is fine, except many of the them were old, dirty and slick as hell.  Maybe they think if you are training for limestone you might appreciate some slick holds?  But it just seems like they are not washing the holds, especially the jugs, which don't really need to be slick and nasty for any purpose.  I found lots of spinners, too.  They are not really promoting the brand well when the holds are so old and dirty.In terms of bouldering, the only good problems set while we were there were open-handed compression problems.  Everything else was kind of boring.When I was there, a lot of younger kids were also bouldering.  Nice and enthusiastic, but they liked to spew unsolicited beta, which is poor etiquette.Some of the areas were closed off when we were there because they were cleaning the floor.  I'm used to gyms doing that at night after closing, not in the middle of the day so that was kind of weird.Interesting old outdoor climbing photos at the entrance.  Someone took the time to poke out almost everyone's eyes in the photos, which was kind of creepy.  But we could recognize a lot of the climbs, which was fun.No drinking fountain so bring your own water or be prepared to buy for $2 a pop.

Amazing experience today! It was my two daughters, and my friend and i's first time but the staff made sure that it won't be our last visit. Brad, a cool, friendly guy made sure we got checked in and had all of our equipment quickly and efficiently. Isaac was our instructor and let me tell you! The patience he had with us was great. I mean it took us forever just to learn to tie the knot correctly and he never showed frustration or impatience with us. He made sure we were safe in all of our safety checks and movements (once we finally got off he ground lol). My daughters loved it! A good physical and mental workout! Will definitely be back!

Some good clean fun! And by clean I mean you will get chalky powder all over yourself. Even if you're not chalking your hands its floating around in the air and gives your hair a nice beach texture. XDClimbing the rock walls was definitely my favorite- I'm a beginner so I completed a 5.6 and attempted a 5.7 but by then I was all tuckered out from the bouldering. This one is kinda scary cuz even if you make it up one rock path you're on your own getting down cuz there's no harness or anything. But fear not, they have cushy landing pads all over. $19 for a day pass? I was there for a couple hours and it came with shoe rental. I believe harnesses are extra but I borrowed from my friend. You have to sign a waiver and orientation form before you can go in. They have a couple lockers in the bathroom that you can use- just need to bring your combo lock if you're going straight from work like I was. Woo I'm gonna be sore tomorrow! Would probably come back again and hopefully take a belaying class.
Workers are really nice! Safty first but laid back atmosphere. It was a blast for my two boys and me ages 16yrs and 9yrs old. I recommend to anyone looking for something challenging and fun!!

Great climbing place and a great deal for students. $28 (I believe) for a monthly student class gives you access to shoes, unlimited entries into the gym for an entire month, and access to their yoga and climbing classes. They routinely change up their walls so you never get bored, and the people are very friendly and always willing to help you. It's an awesome place, especially if you go with friends!

I have been a member here for about 3 months and it has a good variety of top roping and bouldering routes. They change the rocks every couple of weeks which is a plus since the gym is quite small. It's only $28 for a membership if you're a student, which is well worth the money because you get access to all 5 Hangar 18 gyms scattered around the OC.  I would recommend coming early in the afternoon or after dinner as it can become quite packed from 4-7 on weekdays. I'm only giving 4 stars because the gym doesn't have that many top roping routes, maybe 10 at most unless you feel comfortable leading.
Fun time! Our instructor Matty was awesome. She was very detailed and helpful. The place was clean and body odor free!

Compared to the Hangar 18 in Hawthorne, the Hangar 18 is Upland is way better.The Hangar 18 in Upland is nice.  It seems bigger to me... but I'm probably wrong.  I think the one in Hawthorne is bigger.I just like the one in Upland more. What I like about the one in Upland is that if you go in the daytime, they leave all their doors open.  So there's a nice draft that blows through from the one end of the gym to the other.  There's always a fresh breeze blowing so there's no smell to it.The locker rooms are alright.  There are lockers you can put your stuff in.  And a good enough space to change clothes if you need to.Parking is alright.  There's not as much parking as the Hangar 18 in Hawthorne.

Free rentals and lessons with the month membership, so even if you're trying it for the first time, I recommend that you at least get a month membership.  It doesn't cost that much more and you get to go as many times as you want for a whole month!  When I went, there was a groupon for 2 1-month memberships, which I was able to split with a friend.The staff are all really friendly and knowledgeable.  They also do a pretty good job of staying attentive to make sure that beginners are doing everything correctly, for safety purposes.The place seems to get busier near the end of the month as well (I overheard that the reason is because everybody's trying to use up their free guest pass for the month, which is kind of confusing to me).

Great value with Groupon or student pricingKnowledgeable staff, great environment with friendly and helpful climbers.Every few weeks they change the climbs so it never gets old and repetitiveIt's basically the opposite of the regular gym where everyone wears headphones and is antisocial. Here most everyone is friendly and almost no one wears headphones
