This place was a joke!I tried to go there today with my kids.  Not very kid friendly at all.  I spent about 10-15 minutes filling out paperwork then was told I needed to wait 15-20 minutes for the next class to sit through a 45 minute video or intro lesson for me, the adult to them have my kids do rock climbing.I had called and asked if they take reservations which I was told they don't.After waiting another 20 minutes without any other word, I left.What bugged me the most, the staff was not accommodating at all for me and my kids.Isaac was the guy in charge who I talked to and quite frankly could care less about helping us at all. Very poor customer service skills.I saw about 2-3 small groups there that was not happy either.  One guy who you can tell knew what he was doing asked "am I going to get a rope as we have been waiting", while another group that had just came in was frustrated with the start up or actual no start up of his lesson.I was coming in for a "kids intro lesson" which said I needed to accompany any kids under 14, which I did.  The business needless to read the definition of "accompany" which is to go somewhere with as a companion or escort.  So that does not say, I need to rockclimb and or buy a intro lesson as well.  It just means to be there with them.  I heard, "are there any more helmets" of which the answer was no.You can't have that many people at your business and not have enough staff to help.This place needs a management overhaul.

You daughter and I have been climbing for about 2 months now. We have never had a bad experience and have grown to really enjoy the sport. The staff at hanger 18 in upland is exceptionally great. Especially David, he takes extra time to make sure everyone is safe, and happy.

This is the first indoor rock climbing place I have ever been too. I bought a Groupon, buy one get one free deal for $30 intro pass. First impression when walking in the building was "WOW" high walls, lots of variety. But when I got to the front desk I was quickly "WOW'd" at the way they didn't welcome us and said "What do you guys need?". Not a good first impression of the staff. He ended up being nicer as the day went on and in the belay lesson, but he did not give a professional welcome for my store greeting. I even told him I had a Groupon and he looked so confused and said "Well I don't know which one you have." Why I only gave a 3? One because of the customer service and lack of professionalism by the staff. You don't know who works there because no one wears a uniform or badge, nothing. Two because it was dirty. Dust, chalk and filth was covering things. Some of the rocks were so covered in stuff that you couldn't tell what the colors were. If I was rating solely on fun...I would give Hanger 18 a 5 star. I quickly got myself over the dirtiness because I wanted to have fun. But I took a shower immediately when I got home....when I got back to my car I also sanitized my hands. Recommendations: rent chalk bags, have  more comfortable seating for people resting or watching climbers.
Nice climbing gym with a ton of walls to climb. Came here with a friend and got a belay lesson from Brad (who is freaking awesome btw). Rest of the day we tried a bunch of walls and boy was it fun.

Ever want to feel like a bad ass?? Just try out some indoor rock climbing at Hangar 24, and you'll be ready to take on the world. I was introduced through a groupon deal, and ended up taking my fiance with me to redeem it. We both enjoy exercising and are open to adventures, so this was a great daytime date for people like us.You need a partner for belaying, so pick a good one. You do have to trust them with your unbroken bones! Javier in Upland showed us the ropes (literally!) and was a fantastic instructor! He was very informative about belaying & thorough where we felt very comfortable being first-timers. He guided us through the whole process until we felt comfortable and didn't have any more questions, then we were out on our own. I'd return for some more bad ass daytime dates with my buff babe! I'd suggest you do the same, or at least just find your own buff babe, then think about Hangar 24. ;)

Isaac was a straight up turd went for the beginners class and definitely will not be going back here due to the staffs disrespect and unprofessionalism no matter how relaxed your job is there is no reason to be such a shitty group of staff in a what's supposed to be a fun placeExtremely dirty doesn't look like they ever wash or even try to rub anything down. Saw the guy putting shoes kids just used right back into the bins he gave them to me in without cleaning as I was leaving which was pretty disturbing

Hangar 18 Upland was the place of my first introduction to climbing. I'm afraid of heights but got over it and just went for it with climbing. The Upland location is cool because it has top roping, bouldering, and a second floor where you can have corporate events or parties. To be able to top rope, you have to take a lesson with one of the Hangar 18 employees. You can just jump on the wall for bouldering. This place is great for kids and adults! My only issue with the Upland location is that the routes don't get changed often.

We came on a Monday night and the gym was stuffy and hot due to the weather outside, so I guess they have no A/C. Bikram rock climbing, much? In the beginning, we bouldered while waiting for the next belaying lesson. On that day at least, Hangar seemed to have more bouldering than climbing options, with a lot of routes for the former at the back of the gym. The belaying instruction and safety lecture is more comprehensive than I'm used to, lasting at least 20 min. Our instructor was a very well-rehearsed though bored-sounding young employee. If you're not already certified or feel comfortable belaying, make sure you factor in the wait time for a lesson and get here early enough to enjoy a significant amount of time climbing.

Wow, the young guy with blonde hair (Mason I think) is a PRICK! I called at 7:30 and asked if I could still renew my membership for $5 and he said, "Yea but you have to come in person and we close in 30 min". Since today was last day I sped over there and made it by 7:55. Before I could even say anything but "Hey.." he cut me off and said "Sorry I closed the register already and there's nothing I can do". The other guy working there kept looking at the clock,  knowing they are not technically closed yet. I think he totally did it on purpose. Listen dude, don't work there if you are always gonna had a bad tude and sour face and look at everyone like they're annoying you! If you don't wanna hand out shoes to people who just wanna have fun, then go find some thing better to do. Be a yoga teacher, maybe some meditation will help you. Besides this unwelcoming and ungrateful guy who hates his job, the place is alright. I would CHECK OUT SENDER ONE CLIMBING IN SANTA ANA. It's way nicer, has a gym and lounge area.

I just went with my kids. We had a blast the staff is so helpful and friendly. Before you can  climb you need to take a lesson on how to use the equipment ask for eric he does a great job and made us feel very comfortable with what we were doing, because of his personality and helpfulness we will definitely be back again. This place is awesome for the whole family

SMELLS LIKE FEET, but I'm still a fan! I don't think they'll ever be able to get rid of that smell unless they invent a great ventilation system for the place and our feet. BEWARE: This is probably not Hangar 18's fault, BUT be weary of those groupon deals or any online deals. I bought this deal online, "For $30, you get two 60-minute rock climbing lessons, two full days of climbing after your lessons, and rental equipment (a $60 value).", but when we arrived, they told us that groupon had worded it wrong and that we only get one full day of climbing, total! We actually only got one (less than 60-minute ) climbing lesson, too. Trickery! They sure know how to get you with those deals, but I'd say it was still worth it. Besides Boomers, this was my first true rock climbing experience. I tested my muscles and made it to the top of everything I set my mind to. I wish the groupon deal was true because I would've definitely wanted to go back to try a more difficult level or get to the top of those mad rocks (walls with no ropes or harnesses used). *Kisses biceps* Nice staff and some impressive looking regulars, inspiring! You'll definitely break a sweat, increase your heart rate, and at the end of the day, come out of this place smelling like feet. How hot are you!

I have been coming here on and off for years and I really do like it.Pros: - It's fun and takes my mind off the stress of the day- There is something to climb whether you're alone or in a group- There is a large variation if difficulty, so beginners will have a good time and so will veterans-  This is close to home and is much more entertaining than a traditional gym- The employees seem to be very knowledgable - A membership gives you access to multiple clubs in Southern California - There are yoga classes in the facilityCons- The neighborhood seems a little rundown, I wouldn't leave anything of value in my car or leave my car unlocked- it can get pretty stuffy especially in the heat and when it is busy- There is a smell, but you get used to it

A review strictly for the Yoga classes since I haven't seen one posted yet.Yoga with Jenny on Tuesdays and Thursdays - great class and a great work out. She welcomes all levels of yogis. I've been attending the classes for about a month now and I really enjoy it. I'm a beginner to yoga and was a little skeptical at first but Jenny made the transition for easy and relaxing. I mentioned to her that I was new so she paid extra attention to me on my first day; making sure my postures were correct so I wasn't hurting myself. In fact, as the weeks went on, she did that with a lot of the newcomers. Just mention that it's your first class and she'll adjust your body if needed. The classes are not advanced (I would think you'd need to go to an actual yoga studio for those), but some of the poses can be challenging. It's 1 hr and 10 mins long (usually)...the last 5 mins are spent lying in corpse pose. I appreciate this since corpse pose only requires you to lie flat on your back and wind down from the workout so it doesn't eat into the hour doing more challenging poses.Yoga mats are provided for you but I would HIGHLY recommend bringing your own. The mats they have are very run down and very dirty. I can't imagine doing child's pose on one of those. Yuck. One more thing - if you're looking for a quiet yoga session, this is the wrong place for you. The yoga takes place upstairs, out in the open. So there's a lot of background noises from the climbers. I'm not looking for a serious yoga practice but as an addition to the climbing membership, it's definitely worth it.

I've gone here a few times and it's a good climbing gym, although nothing beats climbing outdoors. Anyway, the times I've been here, the place is fairly busy.  They have a good mix of bouldering and climbing routes.  The bouldering routes are on one side and the climbing on the other. There is also an upstairs for the younger bunch.  I don't boulder, so I've only tried the v0, which were fun.  They rent shoes and harnesses and will also give a belay lesson (at an extra charge) to those who are new to climbing. They use a grigri for belaying. The climbing routes vary from the low 5's to probably a 5.12 or so. I typically climb the 5.7- 5.9 range here. The climbs are definitely pumpy and require some dyno moves.  There are some climbs that have an overhang, which are always fun to try and problem solve. The good thing about indoor climbing is that I don't have to worry about injuring myself on a fall, provided that my belayer is paying attention, of course.  Also, if there is a route you want to try, but it's not set up, you can always ask the front desk person to set it up for you and they'll find someone who'll do that for you.I recommend this place to those of you who want to try climbing for the first time and need to learn the basics such as the commands and how to belay.  Although, I do have to admit that I don't belay the way they taught and I don't use a grigri either. Have fun and safe climbing to you!

Love this place for rock climbing, they always have deals which is when I usually go! A lesson, shoes and all day of climbing. I've been here maybe about 3-4 times now and everyone is pretty nice !They always change the courses every so often because I haven't seen it the same twice! Too bad there isn't one closer, I have to drive about 1hr and 15min to get here :(  I do love coming here though, they sell chalk, have a nail cutter if you need it, stable mats for bouldering and all their equipment is great!

I am learning how to lead climb, and I think this place is great. The routes are clearly labeled and have fun names. The walls are higher than their Southbay location, and the staff and other members are really helpful.The lead climbing class series is free for members (I was on the wait list for three months, though). It lasts four weeks and covers a specific topic each week: Clipping techniques, lead belaying, falling, and setting up anchors / rappelling with an ATC. I found it extremely helpful to break it down this way because it gave me plenty of time to practice the concepts.Overall, a pretty good climbing gym.

Great climbing fun, for beginners and those more experienced. If you live within 10 miles from here, you'll probably run into someone you know, which is always a fun surprise! The only thing is the people who work here.. Aren't always interested in helping you or answering your questions. They're often distracted or unwilling to give good customer service. However, keep that in mind and just come and climb on your own or with your friends and you'll enjoy it!

This place was average compared to other rock wall gyms I've been to. Limited space, pretty short heights for the walls. Not sure if it was my allergies or if it was the equipment/building but I was sneezing a storm. I've been to other rock walls and did not have the same sneezing effects. I would say if this is your first time going, this place is fine to check out

Bought a groupon for a month membership for me and my gf hoping we would like it, and wow did we ever! Our instructor eric was a super laid back dude that guided us through the saftey part of everything, after we did ropes they have a boulder area which is freakin awesome i highly suggest people try this. super great environment people stare but everyone is friendly

Had my daughters 7th birthday here.  It was fabulous. The kids had the best time!!!!  The staff was wonderful, kind and thoughtfull.  Could not ask for anything better.  Other parents are already saying they want to have their parties there.

I took a friend here for her birthday, and I'm pretty much hooked. It was the first time for the both of us, and Javier was patient, totally awesome, and super helpful as he showed us how to belay properly.Bring some water or a few bucks for drinks because scaling these walls like a monkey sure does leave you thirsty. Watch out for shaky limb syndrome as you scale those heights because you go a lot higher than you think, and don't forget to try out the boulders. They're a ton of fun!

Came here with my cousin and sister. It was packed and HOT. Lots of fans to circulate air. We had to wait about an hr to get a tutorial on now to belay correctly. Kinda annoying since we were told that it was every hour. BUT we got the last tutorial and it was just us.

Likes: Fun! Not too crowded on a weekday afternoon but crowded during the weekend.  Rates seem decent. Friendly staff who will give you a free refresher course if you want.Dislikes: Slow service in the front sometimes.

My daredevil friend Nikki was in town and asked if I wanted to go indoor rock climbing I said yes, not knowing what I getting into.  The place is in an old warehouse in downtown Upland (you would never know it is there) and has very high ceilings so the walls go up almost 90 feet or so.  They have all levels of climbing and offer a "training" course before you start.  The place is what you would expect for a rock climbing gym sure it smells but that is part of a gym, I mean hello people are changing their shoes in there.  You get a really good workout.I had a great time and will most likely bring my husband back.

I don't think this place smells terrible at all.I went in under my friend's pass and everything was included!! That's an immediate plus to the beginning of my bouldering journey.I'm told that the problems are changed every month or so which is an awesome way to keep things fresh.  What makes the situation even better for me is the extreme friendliness of not just the staff but also the other patrons of the gym.  People cheer you on as you're working on a puzzle and give you advice as your sitting there wondering how your forearms can burn so much!The location isn't beautiful, but then again it's a rock climbing gym so you can't really fault the simplicity of the matter.  Only reason it's not a five star is the routes can be a bit difficult to determine, some of the holds colors are too similar to each other... this makes it difficult for a beginner like me to NOT cheat, haha ;)Come give Hangar 18 a shot!
think depends on how many ppl are inside but it can stink..with all the sweat from ppl..but its a very nice indoor rock climbing place but the size can be little bigger

Love it here!!! Everyone is super nice. I really enjoy bouldering here rather than using the belay. I just got into rock climbing so I'm pretty beginner but I would say they have a good range of sets for all levels!

I've never been a member, but the few times that I have come here as a guest have been great! The facility is always clean and very accommodating. If I was an avid climber I would definitely become a member

This is the first climbing gym that we went to, after seeing it in the local classes forever.. My daughter decided that she wants to climb, so we took her. She is 7 and loved it! She is also very girly, so I was concerned that she would be 'scared off' by all the testosterone in the place, but find out that there is a nice mix of both guys and girls, and there were even some kids there.  The instructor (Javier) was awesome and friendly. She decided that she wanted to get a membership and here we are- figure 8 knots all set up!  The routes are a good mix for the beginners to experienced and it's a fun place to have a group.  Good work out- she is tired, sweaty and hungry after!There is a nice thing that they do offer different types of passes. It's not cost effective to have a membership for a kid ($40+/month) but they offer a punch card and allow her dad to belay her.  Nice sale in August for those that want to try it out without putting in too much $.  But you can get a day pass as well and the staff has a class to show you the ropes. So to speak.

Made reservations at Hanger 18 in Rancho Cucamonga, for my 6  rand Kids, when we got there for Rock Climbing, the place had no ropes, he suggested that we go to upland, there the guy said the kids were to young and was rude and didn't even know what their paper work said, but even there, their paperwork said if with adult they were fine, we called the Riverside Hanger 18 and explained what we wanted and he said come on down he was very helpful and the kids had a gread time. DO NOT WASTE YOU TIME AT THE UPLAND BRANCH. GO TO RIVERSIDE ONLY

I loved this place.. Place was awesome the staff were really friendly & helpful.. thought us how to use the rope & it was fun ^_^ time here went by sooo fast.. had an awesome time with my fiance  & my step daughter..

Exited right after I talked to the guy in front.  He cannot be any more rude.  He spoke as if he was so irritated by my askings about some pricings.  So yea, never coming back to this place.  Have a great business guys.

this place is awesome! they guy at the front desk was very friendly & gave my girlfriend & i helpful tips since we're first time climbers. he showed us where all the V0's are (which is the beginner level) & gave us pointers as we started climbing. it was really busy for a friday night but we were able to boulder everything we wanted to. really fun & i can't wait to go back. pretty cheap if you come for a date. can't wait to come back! everything was really clean & they have 'community' chalk so you don't have to buy any.

with a groupon deal who can resist trying something different. so two of my friends, my bf, and myself went. with the groupon deal we got belay lesson and shoes for a low cost. the lessons were super helpful and the staff was very patient and nice.if you're like me who is quite girly and do not use your upper body strength then you will find it challenging. i was quite scared at first because i'm scared of heights. i remember trying to climb the easiest one first 5'5 then when i finally got to the top i was scared and didnt have a clue how to get down. it was scary! after the first two climbs i got better but my hand was definitely not getting any better. it was harder for me to grab onto the colored rock because it was in so much pain. it feels like rug burn on my hands. we purchased a $4 bag of chalk there more than enough to share and still have leftovers. however the chalk was not great quality. halfway up the chalk was no longer on your hands. if your hands doesn't normally sweat they will. chalk is needed!!!the shoes will freaking hurt! makes you feel like you have super long toe nails and its being squished in the shoe. you're supposed to climb the one color by grabbing/stepping on the same colors. if you're stepping on the other colors to get up its called cheating! so following the colors are pretty challenging! Tip: wear comfortable clothing. have short nails. bring a hair tie if your a girl. wear clothes you don't mind getting dirty because you'll have chalk all over the place. don't wear glasses and put your contacts on! wear socks!restrooms: there is a small locker. no paper towels only dryers.  they sell cold drinks i.e. gatorade for $2 each. there's a few big fans around. there's an upstairs and a downstairs. upstairs is a smaller area. i had fun. definitely a great new experience. i say try it! it won't be something i'll want to do all of the time but maybe once in a while!expect to be sore the next day and possibly a bruise or two because i have one on my knee. happy climbing folks!
staff was an asshole to another staff. accidentally bumped into him and the other guy went into rage mode. he doesn't give a shit. walls are fantastic tho hahahh

My brother (review below) and I went here yesterday. The facility is basic. Lots of good bouldering areas. But we felt (compared to some other places we went to) it wasn't geared for us, not complete beginners but not advanced. We got their at 10:30, and were signed in and harnessed by 10:40. It then took until 12:10 to actually start climbing!!!!! The guy at the desk made it seem like we could get through the class quick, but the class didn't start for 30 minutes and then it was 2 additional pairs of people to us. The instructor, nice guy and just trying to make sure people are safe, was taking fooooorrreeeevvver. And a couple of times made my bro and I wait for no reason. Like I would ask if we could climb and he would say wait, while he finished with some other people. Really the most frustrating moment was when we asked if we could keep climbing and he made us wait 3 minutes, just to point at us and another group and say we were good to go. Come'on man, 3 more wasted minutes. It was pretty frustrating. We were on a schedule and didn't have 1.6 hours to waste just on getting set up. Once through the climbs were okay. It might not be fair because we had just been to an awesome setup in Norcal.Hangar 18, I know you're a little smaller, but what really would boost the place would be some extra things to do like balance beams or roll boards, simple and don't take up room but really add an extra dimension.

I've been rock climbing quite a few times and for the size they do a decent job making as much use out of the area as possible. What really disappointed me was I couldn't just show the people on staff I knew what I was doing and they made me take an hour and half training course before my brother and I could climb. We had a very limited time there and to spend over half just to do the orientation was very upsetting. It felt like the gym is ment for more advanced climbers as the rope courses were jammed in one corner. All in all I probably wont go back

My husband and I like to climb but haven't been in a few years so we got a lesson to be safe. Isaac booked us in and took the lesson. I think that it is safe to say that he works there because he likes to climb and not because likes people but he taught us what we needed to know, and I felt like he did a thorough job of that. Loved the levels of the walls and had a great time. We will be back.

This was my first time doing indoor rock climbing & my experience here was great!lemme just clarify this first, the reason I decided to take off 1 star is because the first time we came in here with our groupon, the guy told us that he couldn't train us / do the 1 hour lesson because they had a birthday party gathering and that he was the only one working so he couldn't assist us. This was rathering upsetting considering I drove all the way to upland, hoping to use the deal since it was about to expire and that day was the best day to go. But hey, what can I do. We ended up finding time to come again before the expiration date.Tips:- I don't think they provide chalk for you to climb... I believe you have to purchase a bag & I'm not sure how much it costs for a bag- Not that much parking, it's sort of in those lot parking with a lot of gravel / unpaved roads (& it's right next to a residential area)- We got the groupon deal for $15 including the 1 hour lesson & shoe rental, etc. (yes, they give you shoes to wear to climb, you can't wear your own regular sneakers!)- The lesson was exactly an hour & he covered all the safety issues, tying ropes, climbing, helping the other person come down, etc. The instructor was very informative and knew everything there is to know about rock climbing. He was very trust worthy & nice!- There is a bouldering area as well where you just climb yourself up there but you don't need any ropes to assist.- They have big fans around the place so it doesn't get too stuffy / hot inside so that's always a plus- There's also an upstairs rock climbing area but it's small and I believe it's for beginners / kids since it doesn't go that high up lolAll in all, it was a great time!! I dont' think I will go back anytime soon just because I don't have upper body strength and it only takes a couple of steps for me to get tired lol fail.

From looking at the website I thought this place would be bigger. I was excited to finally find a large indoor rock climbing facility in southern california! But my expectations and hopes were too high because although it was larger than many other ones i've been to in SoCal, it's still not as great as Mission Cliffs in SF. Mission Cliffs apparently has set the bar too high!It was $19 to climb and rent shoes for a day. I only came to do some bouldering. The employees were chill and helpful. I signed my waiver and paid the fee (but not without trying to find some sort of discount -there were no promotions going on though). It was crowded on this rainy saturday afternoon! There were people ranging from their tweens to early/late 20's.Unfortunately they had a lot of water leakage from their roofs. It was raining heavily and they had to put buckets to catch the dripping water around the place. It caused some of the mats to be wet and cold! I don't know if I'd come here again but I had a good time regardless!

They have a great climbing gym. Good equipment. Easy to extra hard routes. Overall, it is a good rock climbing gym.They do, however, have an absolutely terrible staff. Rude, ignorant, etc. Their policies around the membership are pretty wierd and get you locked into doing certain things. They dont have an air conditioner, so it gets hot! Many of the people who work here are just highschoolers who dont know how to use their database and can barely check you in. They really need better management.I know that the whole point of this place is a hip, edgy enviroment... but customer service is still key. Dont raise your voice at me, especially when i am being nice with you.

I have been here several times and it's great, but unless you're an expert, you NEED a SECOND PERSON otherwise you're waiting for someone to help you and you can be waiting a while.The staff is great, nice and patient and they'll have you climbing in no time.  The prices are very resonable.  I used to have a membership there, but I got really busy and ended up cancelling it.  I do hope to get back there sometime though.I highly recommend it. Good for most ages and all levels of experience.  Live life and go for it! :)

This wasn't my first time rock climbing but it's been awhile. Went with my friend and this place is located in a warehouse in a somewhat residential neighborhood. Not much of a looker on the outside but it's the inside that matters haha.I feel like all the gyms are pretty similar to me because I don't know much about the differences. But they had the usual caves and fun puzzles varying from different difficulties. The day I went they had a small kid's birthday event which was pretty fun, looked like all the kids enjoyed it.The staff were pretty nice and the entire place including the restroom was pretty clean. I would come back again for sure.

My husband and I bought a groupon for an intro class and climbing for a day and it was well worth it! We came on a Saturday afternoon and it wasn't as crowded as I expected it to be, which was really nice. It was easy to find the location and parking wasn't an issue at all. After signing the waivers, we jumped right into our intro class on how to handle all the equipment and the safety guidelines. Our instructor was nice and funny, extremely helpful, and very patient. She made us feel at ease and made sure we felt comfortable before having us climb on our own.Overall, I had a great time and will definitely be coming back :) BTW, I read in a lot of past reviews that there was a nasty stench in the air and to my surprise, I didn't smell anything out of the ordinary. Thank goodness.

Great indoor climbing gym. For $30 I got a belay lesson, shoes, use of the facilities. I came with 2 friends the day AFTER a groupon deal so it was swarming with people! Fortunately, most of them were just hanging out and watching. Didn't smell like feet and wasn't stuffy considering the amount of people sweating.They have a variety of levels to climb on and are well labeled, perfect for a beginner like me. I will definitely come back and will pay $21 since I've already taken the lesson. Dave is really nice and helpful. He actually teaches outdoor adventure classes at Pomona College, and he's a Claremont McKenna College alum. Cool!Random location, as Stowell was a bit hard to find, but it's worth the hunt =)
Love it there. The people are great and it is a fun workout.
Went there on a Sunday, Isacc is very friendly and knowledgable of everything related to the nature and rock climbing, will definitely come back to rock climb more. Highly recommend this place!

Monthly student membership for this gym is $28. A little steep if you're not serious about climbing, but if you do come at least twice a month, it's well worth it since it comes with free rentals too. Each month you get a free guest pass that includes rentals. The shoes are kinda nasty, like they haven't changed them in years, so you probably want to bring your own or at least bring socks. The only complaint is that there aren't that many top roping routes, but there's plenty of bouldering space. Week nights between 5 and 8 this place is packed.

Great local indoor climbing spot!  My friend and I came here after buying a month of membership online.  The staff was extremely nice and helpful the entire time we were there.  The customer service was great and you can tell that safety is their number one priority here. We learned how to belay today and had enough time to try 4 different rock climbs each after our belay lesson. Looking forward to coming back especially to attend their yoga classes.

As a beginning rock climber I found a lot of routes that were a perfect challenge for me.  There is no need to feel intimidated! Just make sure you bring a friend your first time so that you can take a 101 type lesson.  Everyone here is pretty independent, including the staff.  They aren't too helpful, unless you take the initiative to ask questions.  There are also a lot of young college students from the surrounding schools.  Everyone is pretty chill and polite.  If you are a student, be sure to ask for the monthly student discount! I believe it's $28.  Best price I've seen around.

INDOOR ROCK CLIMBING FROM THE BEGINNER'S PERSPECTIVE: This is a great first date place! It completely eliminates any awkwardness because then once you get there, you just strap yourself on a harness and climb on! However, when I first got there, there was a huge line. It was super crowded on a Wednesday night. It seemed to have a lot of college students. Their monthly membership is only $28/month if you are a teacher or student. Sa-weeeet! But I paid $21 including the rental fee for the harness and the shoes. (My vibrams wouldn't have worked here...) Then, they have these "bouldering" walls. Me personally, I couldn't get a good grip but I saw others that were just climbing like Spiderman. THEN, they have the giant walls where you strap yourself onto the harness. It helps to go with someone who is a well-informed climber because if it gets crowded, they may not be able to give you a good tutorial (and trust me, when you are that high up...you want to know what you are doing!) So then, I go to my wall, everything is marked 5.something and the second number varies in difficulty. I was definitely looking for 5.1 and the lowest I saw was 5.5. Deal! I'll take it. You then follow your respective colors and climb on! BUT if I were following "yellow", not gonna lie, I cheated and had to step on blue or purple a couple of times. Here's where it gets CRAAAZY! I was on top of the wall and feeling awesome that I conquered it (and while doing so, I had to have complete trust in my belayer-person) BUT THEN, I hear someone fall! I tried to calmly come down, and then once I got down, I freeeaaked out! Holy Mack! Someone FELL! But the staff reacted VERY well! They immediately called the ambulance and the person was going to be okay. There are a lot of mats that give the climber confidence. But for my first time rock climbing, the last thing I want to hear is someone falling while I am 50 feet high....(I'm not sure how high the walls are but it sure felt high!) As for the location, it is a bit seedy. But once you get inside, the facility is great with cubby holes for your gear and clean bathrooms! Gooood times overall! :)

This was my first climbing gym experience. I had a group of 26 kids. For what it was the prices were good. There is a $60 group fee, and then there is an additional $14/climber for all-day use. That included a one-hour lesson for our group. The staff were super chill, friendly, and experienced. They were there to help us to have a safe and fun time and they had fun doing their jobs.They can handle all skill levels. Shoes and/or helmets are available for the asking. I saw very young kids as well as very experienced climbers. This was a fun place for everyone.

I brought my girlfriend here for us to try something new together and we had a great time. The service was great and our instructor was clear without taking forever to get us started. We will be back soon!

Awesome place to get a full body workout!!! Yea, my hands are torn up....Yea, I'm sore as hell.... And  YEA I'm hooked!  Hangar 18 is clean, spacious, and has many rocks to climb.  Everything is tagged and organized well.  Can't wait to go back and boulder!

I love coming here, I've checked out the Rancho hangar 18 and it was great, but didn't compare to the upland location. My only gripe about this place is that I wish I opened an hour or two earlier, even if it were just the weekends.

Took the wife there for her birthday, and we've been going 2x a week for over 2 months now. It's an excellent workout and a lot of fun. The wife enjoys it a lot, and I enjoy the strategy involved with climbing up the walls, its almost like an obstacle course at times. However, I must admit that at times, people fail to listen to the rules and take unnecessary risks. Just remember to always have fun and be safe.
Great Time! - Spent Mother's Day 2011 with family & friends who were in from Germany! None of us wanted to leave we could have spent the whole day there! Great staff - Thank You!

I had high hopes for this place but it was a complete letdown.I came with 4 friends, but we left within 20mins without climbing anything. One receptionist even tried to stop us from getting our refunds. His attempted guilt-trip, "Did you guys touch the walls? If you did, we can't refund you." I lol'd.My friends and I all had climbing experience, but just not at Hangar 18. I don't understand why we had to pay another $50 for a simple lesson on using a belay device. I understand different gym use different devices, but the gym I go to teaches for free. At least Hangar 18  should provide this service for free. Chalk is additional $4. The gym I go to comes with a free chalk and a chalk bag. Day pass + rental is $20, cheaper than Hangar 18's $21. The routes at Hangar 18 are dirty, dusty and sometimes slimy. Moreover, there are no stickers, so good luck climbing that confusing mess! On that day, I wanted to start with bouldering but the rocks were very uncomfortable to hold and I didn't want to pay $4 for chalk. There were also lots of kids the day I went, and it was very smelly.. On top of that, poor ventilation, disgusting bathrooms with broken dryers, and oddly placed (dangerous) cubbyholes below the routes.. i recommend you stay away from this place. TDLR; Poorly managed gym, and the owners try to scam you with lessons, chalk, and refreshments.

I was extremely impressed with the staff, there was one staff member was like Spiderman. He climbed all the way to the top and just hung there. The atmosphere isn't great because I feel like this rock climbing gym is for the more experienced. Some of the "regulars" there seemed to look down on the people who couldn't quite get the hang of it yet. The routes are more difficult than the ones at Rock City in Anaheim. I went here with a group, and in the beginning, there was an hour long lesson to teach you how to tie the knots and belay. It was a good experience, and I will most definitely be back to conquer these walls.

staff is chill, route setters are good, full pads everywhere for bouldering, and for the monthly price hangar 18 simply can't be beat. wish there was a bit more top roping and maybe a self belay area but all in all it's a great gym.

I agree with Tina B. SMELLS LIKE FEET.Regardless, the people there are nice and Javier did a great job instructing a beginner like me on the basics of climbing and belaying. This was my first indoor rock climbing experience so I have nothing to compare it to, but I had a great time here.  Fun for all ages!

I love this place.  This used to be my "24 Hour Fitness" for over a year, before other things happened.  The staff is almost always cordial, and the familiarity goes both ways.Let's start with the negatives though.  I thought that a lot of the boulder routes tend to be rated lower and lower than some of the difficulty suggests.  Things tend to be aimed either towards shorter or taller climbers, especially the climbs in my limited V0-V4 range.  There was the aforementioned odor...which I usually just think is from condensation and a hot warehouse.  Oh, and the price for membership--$46.  Well, it sounds all well and good that you get to go to the "new" Hawthorne gym and the Riverside gym (which is 2x bigger with a cooler bouldering...boulder?).  But, it's steep, especially since most people can't just go in between one and the other on most days.But, the positives are many.  Dave is a friendly guy, if a bit hard to get a hold of.  Javier is awesome.  Matt is great and funny.  Routes always look interesting and having those V4s cresting the V5 difficulty (or V6 depending on who set it and how tall they are) makes you improve.  They also change them on a semi-consistent basis (read: when the ringers get bored and start doing sick add-ons).But the best part is...well, competitions.  I will be the first to admit that I wasn't ready (fought the flu of pigs the week before, and couldn't even work out and stand for periods over 10 minutes) and that the intermediate class was actually quite skilled.  But, it was a blast.  The place was completely crowded...the adrenaline was high...EVERYONE was rooting for you...and even though my stomach felt more like it was going vertigo than my inner-ear was...it was a blast.  And, it's great for parties!

Compared to the Hangar 18 in Upland, the Hangar 18 in Riverside is way better in terms of cleanliness and routes.  I had visited the Riverside one earlier that month and I did not have to wait to climb, whereas the Upland gym had a limited number of ropes and routes we can climb on.  The overall experience is awesome, but if you want a bigger space, I would opt to to to the gym in Riverside.  Since it feels newer and bigger then this one.However, the staff here was very knowledgeable and friendly.

Indoor rock climbing is a great way to have a bit of fun and get some good exercise and Hanger 18 is an excellent place to do it. The prices are more than reasonable. There are quite a few routes of all different difficulties and the staff members change them reasonably often to keep the variety.I think the best thing about this climbing gym though is the staff, they are all very friendly and show a genuine interest in helping others learn and enjoy this sport.

The reviews stating dirty and confusing layouts of holds are sound. However, this is the only gym I have been to so can't compare it to anything better or worse. The staff on the other hand...not the most welcoming. At one point overheard an employee, or what seemed to be an employee (hard to tell around there), that "anyone not able to climb a v4 should go home." Not cool man. Someone trying climbing for the first time doesn't want to hear that type of talk. Very unprofessional. Going to try out the Riverside location this weekend, lets see how it goes.

First Time Rock Climbing! Whoo!I bought a groupon so my boyfriend and I went on a Friday morning. It wasn't crowded at all. The front desk takes a little warming up to, but they are actually very nice. The guy who gave us the lesson was great, very friendly. I especially liked that he stayed with us for a good 45 minutes making sure both of us knew exactly what to do. The bathrooms are very sterile and kind of nasty and the shoes they give you look like they've never been washed. (-1), but if you can get over your mysophobia, you can have a lot of fun. Quite a workout too!!

We are so happy with our membership to Hangar 18. The staff is ALWAYS helpful, knowledgeable, professional and available. Safety is their number one priority. They create an environment that is encouraging, positive and fun. It doesn't feel like working out, it feels like playing with friends. The setters work hard to set a wide range of climbs for all skill levels. The facility and equipment is well cared for a clean. I can't say enough positive things about Hangar 18. It is absolutely a family friendly, fun place to be and because of the folks at Hangar, I'm hooked for life!

My wife surprised me on my birthday by taking me here.  The experience was awesome.  Staff is friendly with the straight forward and simple instructions.  They treat you well even if you are a beginner.  In no time my wife and I were climbing the wall like spider man.  When we left I was starving, great work out.  The price for membership is great, I almost signed up for it but it's to far away from work. Can't wait to go back again in the near future.

Great place to have a good time and get a good workout. The staff was very friendly with the 24 Hour Fitness staff that went down this morning and we had a blast! Will definitely be referring the facility to other and getting my membership soon.
Went to the one in riverside...great place..super fun times....some upper body strength is needed for this

This place is fun for everyone, maybe you're just looking to try out rock climbing or maybe you're someone who has done this before and wants to test their limits... This is the place has walls for all levels.Well basically they separate it into two parts, the linear (climb up and down) walls or the free walls which could be going up, going down, hanging sideways, jumping wall to wallThe linear up and down walls you have to be strapped into a harness and held by a partner... They have lessons for this, which you have to pay for or you can just have an experienced friend to help you... It's fun and all but it's not as challenging as the free walls. The free walls are way more challenging, left me with lots of calluses and feeling more accomplished if I ever completed it.By the end of the day, I would have a few walls that I couldn't complete due to fatigue and injury. This place I wouldn't say is expensive, but I'd only go once in a blue moon...They have a membership deal if you seek to go a lot to work out or just have fun. Staff is friendly too ++

This was my first time rock climbing, and I had a great time here! Our instructor, Dave, was super helpful and nice. The standard adult price including rental gear is $30 per person. Dave offered us the college student discount of $28 per month membership - first month is free with unlimited access to all their gym, it comes with rental gear, monthly guest pass, and you can cancel any time. Even if you don't continue with their membership, I would recommend trying it out for a month and bring a friend with you the next time you're back. It'll pay for itself!Our belay lesson took a while to get through, but once you get the fundamentals down, it'll be easy sailing! Despite not having any upper body strength, I found that some of the paths were quiet doable and were not as difficult as they appear. Do expect to get a work out whether you're climbing or belaying. When you're done, challenge yourself to the bouldering routes. I was able to latch onto a couple of holds before giving in. The facility was a little stuffy when we first arrived and by the time we were done, the place felt like a sauna. The restroom needs attention. The door on one of the stalls had no lock and the other one was out of toilet seat covers. The floors and counter was wet. An industrial air conditioning unit will be nice especially during the summer months, but sweating makes me feel like I've gone through an intense work out. You can pretty much spend a whole day here easily.

Had mt 10 year old daughter's Birthday Party here. Staff was great, helped carried in party stuff, they have a great area upstairs for the parents and others to hang out.  The guys & gal belaying were great with the kids, friendly/encouraging would definitely recommend this place for a party or just t go climb at. Day is inexpensive so go check it out.

Well first off the worst toilet I've ever seen! Second the staff looks at you like you owe them more then $53.00 membership. With the exception of Isaac who is vary kind and friendly. Third there is no way to tell between the guest or who works there. Four this place just may be the worst place, to go with the exception of Detroit. Fifth the staff will persuade you to do some thing, els so they do not have to belay you. Sixth so If you had made this place the last thing to do on your bucket list then have at!
My company (24 Hour Fitness) held a team event here...what a great time. We had three great instructors and plenty of walls to climb. Great experience all around.

Me? Rock climb?!? If you're surprised, then you definitely know me! But hey - adventure time right!! Hangar 18 is located in Upland on Stowell (off of Euclid) and is hidden behind a few other warehouse looking buildings.  It was our first time going and so my husband and I each paid $30 which included the climbing (you could stay all day), the gear rental (harness, shoes, etc), and the introductory lesson.  They open at 10am on Saturdays and we got there probably around 11 and were pleased to find that we were among the few people there.  They did tell us that on Saturdays there are usually a few birthday parties going on so it could get a tiny bit crowded.  So after signing our life away, we began the lesson.  The guy was SUPER friendly and well informed about climbing (duh) and made it seem easy as pie.  Since it's a pretty small place, you and your partner have to belay for each other.  With the top rope climbing, they have tons of different difficulty levels for you to try throughout the gym.  They also have the "cave"-type area which is just you climbing (no rope) on different angled walls (with some mats underneath to protect you).  It was great because everyone at the gym (employee or not) was super friendly.  Other people would belay for each other and you could hear people shouting words of encouragement for complete strangers.  By the time we left (close to 2pm) the place was definitely getting crowded.  Would I go again... yes - but probably not to climb... I think the fear of falling (no matter how safe it is) is just too strong! But hey, it was a great workout ... I definitely woke up with some sore arms!

Starting off- I am biased towards this gym, It's where I learned to climb & got into the sport I love now.Regarding some other reviews:Yeah, there is a definite foot odor in almost ALL indoor climbing gyms- this one is no exception.  The ventilation does help, so does spraying all the rental shoes with Lysol after each use. Hangar 18 in Riverside (or "Hangar-side") IS bigger & better, because it was built by the owner of Upland Hangar 18 after 25+ years of the Upland gym.  The Hawthorne gym was bought out by hangar 18.  Pros:-Best gym in the area- next closest is Arcadia Rock Climbing- which has next to no roped climbing: it's a bouldering gym (low level climbing with no ropes & big pads to fall on) you need more muscle for bouldering.-Friendly & knowledgeable staff:  Their primary concern is safety, as long as you're not doing something that will injure you or someone else, they will let you do what you want (some gyms don't allow taking shirt off/ shoes off/ climbing without helmet)-low price/ membership price: if you get a day pass, go in the early morning, then again after lunch to get the most out of it.  comparable gyms charge $60-$75 a month- this one is $40/ a month if you sign up with a card & automatic billing (cancel anytime with no fee)-The holds used by the gym are manufactured by the owner, which means you get consistent, new holds to climb on. ("Climb-it holds")-all ages can do it (depending on general fitness)- the youngest I saw was 2 years old (got half-way up the wall) the oldest was probably in his 70's-this pro is more for the ladies: as a result of the no shirt required, and the nature of climbing, there are almost always a couple of topless dudes with super-cut muscles climbing around (regular climbers) that- and some not-so-cut, hairy dudes too- haha-They offer classes for introduction to climbing (how to climb) including belay, rappel, lead climbing, etc.  they also do guided outdoor tours (ask Dave)-color coded routes: some gyms use colored tape, I find it easier to follow the colored holds, than it is to look for tape that falls off sometimes.-theres more pros, but you'll find out when you go here! Cons:-There is NO air conditioning!  this is good if you're planning on sweating anyway, but not so great if you're just here to watch the kids/ take pictures.-The roof leaks when it rains (drips into buckets) gets onto pads & limits where you can climb (still possible to climb)-No early hours: they open @ 10 am daily, so don't plan on a early workout to start the day-

I have been to a good share of rock climbing gyms and have been climbing for several years now.  This gym has all the basics that one needs, but that is about it.  It has high walls and mediocre bouldering problems.  I am writing this review from the point of view of a boulderer since that is mostly what I do.  The holds are really old and worn despite the fact that Hangar 18 actually owns and makes all of their own holds.  I don't really understand why they still need to spray paint over their holds just  to make them a uniform color.  This pretty much ruins the texture of the holds and makes them less gripy.  In compared to the newly built Hangar 18 in Riverside, these two gyms are night and day.  The staff is pretty on top of things here and is very cautious of their patron's safety.  The gym in all is kind of dirty and run down.  Worth a visit if you're in the area for some training, but not a gym that is worth a membership.
I came here because I had a groupon. This was my 1st time rock climbing. The instructor was really nice n helpful n it was definitely a workout lol :)

I signed up for a month of membership and drove in from West LA just to take the lead climbing classes with Dave Hamilton. The classes were well structured and extremely useful for anyone ready to start lead sport climbing. The staff was generally helpful and although there was a mix-up with my membership cancellation, my complaints were handled promptly. Overall a great experience!

This is my home gym and I definitely love it.  I've been to plenty of other gyms and I think that overall the Hangar 18 chain is one of the better gyms I've been to.They opened up a new cave in the back and there's always plenty of routes for my level (v2-v4).Top ropers also have a lot to choose from and there's some great lead climbing routes.Negatives: when it rains, the roof leaks. Also, they've decided to start cleaning on Sunday mornings when the gym is open. That really bothers me because the close off the ENTIRE front portion and first cave leaving only the small back cave open for climbers. I just don't understand why they can't clean when they are closed like every other business.Positives: orderly (a lot of other gyms have kids running around and even parents being a nuisance.  They are very diligent here making sure that everyone is not only safe, but enjoying their time here, so when there is a party of kids, you can't even tell). The routes are changed up a lot so you don't get bored and they are well organized.Someone mentioned that they don't have tape and you can't figure out the routes, but unlike other gym, Hangar matches the color of the hold as well as the tape. So if there's no tape, it's the hold colors that you follow... I think it's much cleaner and easier to follow actually.

YES! I have always wanted to rock climb! The day has finally come. My boyfriend bought us a membership to Hangar 18 as an anniversary present :). We went for the first time a few days ago and I am still sore. It was so much fun! I will say this, rock climbing is an excellent work out! I honestly can not tell you how excited I am to go all of the time. The place is great! It has various climbs with different levels of difficulty. Of course I am working on all of the "easy" ones, but even those can be difficult when your upper body strength is shot. I'm looking forward to improving. In the meantime I urge all of you to go and try it out!

The Inland Empire's best (only one I know of) climbing gym.$15 day pass to climb and boulder.  The facility is pretty large, so you'll be exhausted before you've grown bored of climbing all the different  runs.  Go with someone so you'll have an easier time getting a belayer.The staff is very helpful and "hands off" if you don't need it, but highly professional and knowledgable if you do!  Perfect for those lazy weekend afternoons where you want to get out and do something, but just don't know what to do.

This place might be OK if you don't have any experience, but if you are a climber I highly recommend NOT wasting your time. The routes were abysmal (setters don't know the difference between right and left hand holds, and have no concept of body position or movement). The staff was very unfriendly and one employee dropped a 15 ft. ladder on my boyfriend's foot within our first five minutes of being there!! His foot is insanely bruised and swollen now, and the guy who did it didn't even say sorry. I really can't think of anything good to say about this place and would never go back. It might be a good place for a kid's b-day, but otherwise, consider yourself warned...UPDATE: My boyfriend's foot is actually broken from the ladder incident!! Ug.

Nice small indoor climbing gym with bouldering, top rope, and lead climbing.  Excellent prices for students from the Claremont Colleges.  Membership includes access to the two other Hangar 18 gyms (Riverside & South Bay) which is nice for a change when you get tired of the same old problems.  Can get busy at certain times of the week.

This is probably the best indoor climbing rock facility in all of Southern California- I'm just so sad I moved away! Hangar 18 is an enormous facility that offers harness climbing and bouldering. I've never gotten lessons here, but I know they offer lessons and classes for all ages. And what's hard to believe, is that Hangar 18's memberships are also cheaper than other rock places- a lot cheaper! I moved to LA and have yet to find a place as good and as affordable as Hangar 18. You definitely need to go for a day to check it out!! This place seems to be a good party idea for younger children as well. The staff is super friendly and knowledgeable too. (I really can't get over how sad I am that I no longer live close to Hangar 18!)Parking is free, restrooms and snacks for purchase on site. Climbing includes free shoe/harness rental. (yes, free!) And there are student discounts.

Very kick back atmosphere.  Excellent bouldering paths with overhangs and such.  The walls to sport climb on are high and normally consist of 5 6s to 5 12s for the average climber to play with.  The staff is informative and always willing to lend a helping hand in setting up a top rope of suggesting grabbing methods.Probably the only negative is it can be quite busy during the weekend when parties are going on, can be hella cold in the winter and hella hot and sweaty during the summer.  The last gripe would be the rented shoes have holes that are so big, you can completely see your big toe.Last note is the price for a member in comparison to other gyms is very cheap!
Fun place to work out. Harder than it looks but a great workout for your body and mind.

I have been a member for about 2 years now and this place is awsome there are climbs for beginners and for the pros! It is a completely different work out than a gym work out and will get you shredded real quick if you climb hard. Climbing indoor is a great way to get ready for outdoor climbs and really helps boost your confindence outdoors! If its your first time or don't have climbing shoes wear REALLY thin socks for the shoes.

I love this place. I've climbed at both their Upland and Riverside locations. I'm not an avid climber but I enjoy a workout that is a little more challenging than a treadmill or free weights. The people that work here are super cool and are always willing to help out whether you need help with equipment or you need advice on technique. The crowd that climbs at these gyms range from really young to older and beginners to avid climbers. I have an 8 month old and my husband and I fully plan on introducing her to climbing through these gyms as soon as she's old enough. I would highly recommend visiting either location.

If you like checkin out the booooty this is the place for you!!! haha jk I really liked this place and i had a very fun experience.This was my first time at an actual indoor climbing facility so i dont have much to compare it too.I got there with a group of 14 around 10:30am on a sunday. It wasnt crowded at all. We signed the waivers and got our shoes and harness. It was funny because on the waiver it said basically if i hit the floor they werent responsible lol. but i guess i didnt think about bouldering. It was a pretty big facility though like i said i havent been to one before. There are some small walls to begin on if your a beginner upstairs, then theres quite a bit of walls on the main floor to climb all varying in difficulty. There is also a bouldering area. My belayer i had for the duration of my climbs was very informative, helpful, and easy to communicate with, some other belayers just spotted you and didnt say a word. So the belayer i had made it much more enjoyable and he also let me use his hand powder which helps a lot. Everyone that was there was very friendly and i met a lot of different people. Our time was up at 12:30pm but it started getting quite crowded. The total for the group of 14 was 270 dollars minus the 50 dollars we had to deposit. I feel like we got ripped off because my belayer said day passes were 16 dollars. Overall i had a good experience and will definitely consider going back. Especially since its a fun way to work out. I definitely recommend this place to others, cuz i was told it is better than the other areas around this region. Also enjoy the soreness in your forearms!

WILL NEVER COME HERE AGAIN. I bought a Groupon for two intro classes. We had to wait 45 minutes for a group party to clear out - no problem. When it was our turn (there were two other couples in our class), the employee giving us the class kept running back and forth to the front desk to help other people coming into the gym. He would tell us to practice a knot and then he run over to the front desk and help someone and we would be standing there waiting for 15 or 20 minutes until he returned. This went on for about 45 minutes and at that point we untied our harnesses and left. We asked for our Groupon back and told him that we wanted a refund. He said that they were understaffed and the owner didn't care. He told us to call the owner, Dave, to complain. I saw other employees behind the desk not helping at all.  I don't know what is going on there but I will never return. Save your money and go elsewhere.

It was my first time rock climbing and was nervous. Had  to wait for a while to start with a group class. The class instructor was quick and I felt like he was in a rush. There's one giant fan to cool the entire place. There was a kids birthday party there, so felt like it was a little crowded. The place smelled like sweat hog. Still had fun with my friend.

great fun place for a good workout. it looks easy......and yes, it CAN be easy, but if its your first time, you will be sore. so i've been here a couple times now and i really do enjoy getting my rock-climbing on. the price for a day visit isn't bad, $16...if you only come like once a month or once in a blue moon. but if you're hard core, then spring for the $40 per month membership. ya, pretty steep when you compare it to a regular gym membership. but its all a preference. it is a super fun place to hang out with friends and watch all the shirtless guys trying to out-climb each other lol

I write this review primarily to disagree with Maeve G.'s dispagraging assessment.Route/problem setting:Hangar 18 setters are fairly creative, but the routes and problems they set tend to be 1) right-handed biased and 2) power/dyno biased.  They're better at setting problems than routes, with special emphasis toward overhung problems.  This should come with little surprise to those who know the tight-knit staff and core members, all of which climb/train with indoor bouldering comps as some part of their consideration.  My opinion is that the setting style allows one to get strong very quickly at Hangar, but the particular strengths that are developed don't seem to translate very well to real/outdoors climbing.Staff/core members:As impartial as I can be about this issue... they're a very cool bunch of guys.  They will never hesitate to encourage you at a crux... loudly.  Always there with a spot.  However, they're all 20-somethings, some with a slightly skater-ish, self-assured air to them.  This means that even if they mean well, their mannerisms (esp. in reference to their particular sense of sarcasm and irony) can rub people the wrong way if one is not attuned to it.  That said, it is actually the friendliest climbing gym I've ever been a member of.Shirtless climbing:There's limited ventilation at this gym, and temps can hit into the 90s.  Going shirtless becomes habitual.  Whether that can be construed as arrogant is probably dependent on the insecurity of the construer.Parties:Hangar 18 can become almost unclimbable for members during times when the gym hosts parties for paying groups.  The unfortunate part is that this occurs pretty often on weekends.  On the upside, the belay slaves the gym rounds up to host these parties are "trade members," that is, members who barter belay work for their membership fees.  While one might suspect that this results in less-than-stellar service, the opposite is true, as these "trade members" are people with more love for climbing then money, AKA "dirtbaggers".Overall:For better-or-for-worse, Hangar 18 exudes the aura of being a very UN-CORPORATE (read: "dirtbagger") climbing gym, esp. compared to a chain such as Rockreation (a climbing gym chain in Orange county and West LA.).  I think if your idea is to drop in after work and just climb with your iPod, isolated and focusing into your zone... there are less-crowded and more structured gyms to climb at.  However, if you want to become part of a climbing COMMUNITY, Hangar 18 is a great place to be.

As Samantha L mentioned, Hangar 18 isn't on par with the Bay Area  (or Boulder) climbing gyms, but I've yet to find one in the LA Metro area that is.  That being said, the staff are friendly and are a large number of long steep routes plus a small bouldering area.  The gym is dated with old school biners that used to grace my circa 2000 rack.  The cracks could also stand to be textured.  Unfortunately, the location makes it inconvenient for me to go midweek and there's no way I'm pulling plastic when I can climb outside on the weekends.  Maybe they'll open a Pasadena/Arcadia location (hint).

This place is great! There are tons of great climbs and helpful staff.  The rates here are much better than other indoor rock climbing places! $5 for an entire day if you go M-F before 12 noon.  Only $5 to rent shoes and a harness.  If it's your very first time, the lesson costs $10, which is just a one time thing.It's a great workout, and they also have yoga classes here

i have been to other gyms and hangar is by far the best one i have ever been staff were friendly, prices are ok good place for beginner climber to advanced they reset all the walls every so often so you don't get bored climbing the same old stuff and great monthly rates and personally i like climbing routes that are one color unlike threshold i hate taped routes all in all its good place to come with a family they do have upstairs climbs for the youngsters who are scared but i would definitely be back

Hangar 18 is an awesome rock gym.  I've climbed casually indoors for several years, but not since moving to LA two years ago.  My university has a partnership with Hangar 18 to offer a PE class in rock climbing, so I signed up.  Dave, the manager of Hangar 18, teaches us personally for about an hour and then we get to climb for the rest of the night.  There is a huge variety to climb here, and everybody from beginners to experts will be happy.  It's a little expensive, and some of the regulars seems to have "their territory" reserved, but I was able to climb most of the routes I wanted.  I'm thinking about upgrading to a full time membership after my class is over.

Fun place to try out climbing - definitely a good alternative to a regular work out gym.  My fiancee tried a one month membership in which they were having a deal since the Riverside branch was opening - I think it was around $15 for the first month.  With a membership, you can bring one guest per month and your rentals are included.  You get a lesson on how to operate the equipment but the down side is you have to have a partner, otherwise, you can only do the free climb wall which is pretty difficult and not as high.  The location is a little difficult to find so make sure you mapquest ahead of time.  Also, it gets very hot and stuffy during the summer months - this is an old building so there is no A/C!  Wear comfortable clothes and definitely bring socks if you have to use their rental shoes.

Friends recommended to go to Hangar 18 to try rock climbing. We found this place closer to his home and my first impression here is too crowded, bathroom is so dirty, trash was all over the floor. I did had a great time with my friends. We carry all our belonging with us everywhere we go because there's no locker rental or place to put our stuff. And unfortunately, toward the end of our day before we leave, our camera bag (contain camera and lens) got stolen from either people who work there or the customers. Been trying to go there every single days, talk to them in person and even call and the owner or manager. The owner/manager said the employees and people here are so friendly and work as a team and they don't steal here. I guess my camera bag just grew legs and walk away from me when I turn around. I suggest you do not bring any camera or phone with you in this place because you will end up like me. I will definitely will try rock climbing again, but probably never ever go back to this place.

I have never done any type of rock climbing but I did not have any issues here. They made me feel welcome and I was able to move along to more difficult walls. I wish the prices were lower but the college discounts are still pretty good.

got free tix to this place as a bday gift. what i didnt like was how the dude at the front desk was on his phone playing video games and talking instead of helping us. we had to wait about 15 mins... overall the experience was wonderful and my friends and I really want to come back again

i've been here a couple of times, mostly just to hang out with friends, once to actually try climbing myself. the staff is super knowledgeable and friendly, as are the regulars. it's nice that they let non-climbers hang out; i know it took me a long time to even muster the courage to step into a harness, but watching everyone else totally made me feel more comfortable with the idea. i agree with grace y about the shirtless dudes. that comment really made me chuckle. i think it's better to go during the day when it's less crowded (and humid), just watch out for those large parties. it's really hard to concentrate with small children running around, high off cake and soda pop.
